and tunity for all Australians to acknowledge and help heal the wounds of the many (iii) facilitating the development of a new Indigenous people and their families Indigenous representative body. who suffered as a result of the forced removal policies of successive AustraTaxation (Question No. 3) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 17 November 2004: (1) What proportion of (a) barristers, and (b) solicitors failed to lodge an income tax return on time in each of the financial years ended 1992 through to 2002. (2) What action did the Australia Taxation Office do about this and when was it taken. ber’s question: (1) In preparing the response to this question the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) utilised the relevant data of practising members of the legal profession. The population was identified by matching ATO records against records held by the regulators on the legal profession. The following figures are current as at 30 September 2004. Profession 1999 2000 2001 2002 2003 Barrister 32% 31% 36% 35% 36% Solicitor 28% 28% 30% 29% 28% Statistics prior to 1999 are not included because taxpayer records have been archived and there would be a significant cost to the community to extract the information. (2) The ATO has and is continuing to vigorously pursue the lodgement of all outstanding returns including the use of reminder notices, demands for lodgement, issuing summonses and prosecutions. Further information regarding the ATO’s legal profession project is available in the Commissioner’s 2002-03 and 2003-04 annual reports. Taxation (Question No. 5) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 17 November 2004: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1761 (Hansard8 September 2003, page 18973), how many (a) barristers, and (b) solicitors or lawyers were not up-to-date with the lodgement of their income taxation returns with the Australian Taxation Office in each of the financial years ended 1997 to 2003. (2) What action has the Commissioner of Taxation taken since 1 July 1997 to force members of the legal profession to lodge their income taxation returns with the Australian Taxation Office. (3) What the details of the (a) administrative penalties, and (b) prosecutions taken against members of the legal profession. (4) Can he provide an up to date report on the action taken by the Taxation Commissioner since the release by the Attorney-General and the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer on 2 May 2003 of their press release titled ‘Progress of Government action to strengthen laws to prevent tax abuse’. (5) What is the progress of the Commissioner of Taxation’s investigation to ensure that existing arrangements designed to disadvantage creditors are overturned. ber’s question:
title: Departments Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Brough
theText: The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable mem
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Brough
theText: The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable mem(1) The following table provides details of the number of returns outstanding for the legal profession as at 21 December 2004. Year Barrister Returns Solicitor Returns Outstanding Outstanding (National)* (National)** 1997 34 1,164 1998 30 1,254 1999 32 1,143 2000 39 1,058 2001 46 919 2002 66 1,020 Subtotal 1997 – 2002 247 6,558 2003 239 2,352 Total 486 8,910 *Population 4,521 ** Population 38,016 Note: The numbers for unlodged returns, especially for earlier years, may include taxpayers who did not have an obligation to lodge in those earlier years (for example, a solicitor with an obligation to lodge in 2002 may have been a student not required to lodge in 1997). (2) The ATO has and is continuing to vigorously pursue the lodgement of all outstanding returns including the use of reminder notices, demands for lodgement, issuing summonses and prosecutions. See also data on prosecutions at no. 3. (3) (i) The ATO does not have readily to hand the amount of administrative penalties imposed on members of the legal profession for failing to lodge returns. (ii)The following tables provide details the results of prosecutions of barristers and solicitors from 1997 to 2005 (as at 21 December 2004). Barristers Financial No of Fines Good Com19B Summons Summons Year Taxpayers Behavmunity (Offence Withdrawn Not Served Convicted iour Service found, no Bond Order conviction recorded) 1997 9 $17,450 0 0 1 0 1 1998 11 $22,350 0 0 0 2 1 1999 4 $4,450 0 1 2 0 2 2000 8 $6,300 0 0 3 6 5 2001 13 $24,550 2 0 3 8 4 2002 20 $23,750 1 0 18 28 14 2003 18 $34,300 4 0 4 2 2 2004 10 $29,700 4 0 8 5 3 2005 9 $25,020 3 0 3 3 5 Solicitors Financial No of Fines Good Com 19B Summons Summons Year TaxpayBehav mu(Offence Withdrawn Not ers Coniour nity found, no Served victed Bond Serconvicvice tion reOrder corded) 1997 4 $7,050 0 0 0 0 0 1998 4 $4,000 0 0 1 1 0 1999 2 $5,600 0 0 2 0 0 2000 5 $3,300 0 0 1 0 1 2001 9 $6,500 0 0 0 0 2 2002 11 $10,450 0 0 4 3 4 2003 12 $11,600 0 0 0 1 2 2004 50 $68,100 2 0 30 5 9 2005 46 $98,050 8 0 15 12 9 (4) In response to Recommendation 1 of the Joint Taskforce on the use of Bankruptcy and Family Law to Avoid Payment of Tax, the Commissioner has issued guidelines to ATO staff members, advising them of the circumstances under which the supply of information to insolvency practitioners is permitted under the privacy and secrecy provisions. These guidelines took effect on 30 June 2003. The Commissioner is considering recent advice on the extent to which the existing secrecy provisions allow him to supply publicly available information to various professional bodies and industry associations in accordance with Recommendation 2. On 11 June 2003, in response to Treasury’s request of 20 March 2003, the Tax Office offered its views on Joint Taskforce Recommendation 12 and other alternative suggestions and strategies to deter high income professionals from avoiding their taxation obligations. The Tax Office has since undertaken a significant review of the ATO Prosecution Policy. The outcome of that review will be the publication of a revised prosecution policy which, among other matters, will ensure that Tax Office staff may elect under s.8F of the Taxation Administration Act 1953, in appropriate circumstances, to treat offences otherwise than as prescribed taxation offences. This will enable a broader range of sentencing options (including custodial sentences) to be considered by a court if a prosecution results in conviction. (5) The Commissioner, in his capacity as a creditor, has continued to take action to overturn arrangements designed to disadvantage creditors by funding trustees in bankruptcy to challenge such arrangements in the Courts. The Commissioner is also currently considering the recently released Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia Discussion Paper– Strengthening Bankruptcy AntiAvoidance Provisions. This discussion paper examines possible approaches to strengthening the ‘clawback’ provisions. Taxation (Question No. 13) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, in writing notice, on 17 November 2004: Further to the answer to question No. 1356 (Hansard, 15 June 2004, page 30394) where in the Commissioner of Taxation’s Report for 2002-2003 does it say how many (a) barristers, (b) solicitors, (c) judges, and (d) magistrates failed to lodge a tax return during the financial year ended 30 June (i) 1992, (ii) 1993, (iii) 1994, (iv) 1995, (v) 1996, (vi) 1997, (vii) 1998, (viii) 1999, (ix) 2000, (x) 2001, and (xi) 2002. ber’s question: (a) to (d) In preparing the response to this question the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) utilised the relevant data of practising members of the legal profession. The population was identified by matching ATO records against records held by the regulators of the legal profession. In the chart below judges and magistrates are shown together as Judiciary, as ATO records do not distinguish between the two. The following table shows the number of barristers and solicitors with income tax returns outstanding as at 30 September 2004 and members of the judiciary with income tax returns outstanding as at 14 February 2005. Profession 1996 1997 1998 1999 2000 2001 2002 2003 Barrister 26 34 30 32 39 46 66 239 Judiciary 0 1 1 1 1 4 7 26 Solicitor 1,077 1,164 1,254 1,143 1,058 919 1,020 2,352 Statistics prior to 1996 are not included because taxpayer records have been archived and there would be a significant cost to the community to extract the information. Taxation (Question No. 14) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 17 November 2004: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 3016 (Hansard, 15 June 2004, page 29857), can he say why the Commissioner of Taxation’s Report for 2002-2003 did not explain why the ATO did not detect the members of the legal profession who were operating for many years outside of the taxation system. (2) Will he provide an explanation now; if not, why not. (3) Can he say why the Commissioner of Taxation’s Report for 2002-2003 did not explain why the ATO employed Mr Clarrie Stevens over a period of eight years during which he did not lodge an income tax return? (4) Will he provide an explanation now; if not, why not. ber’s question: (1) and (2) The Commissioner of Taxation’s Annual Report for 2002-2003 focused on current activities designed to address non-compliance with tax laws within the legal profession. The process of identifying those outside the tax system has become more sophisticated with the development of better data matching tools which in the past were not available to the ATO. (3) and (4) The Commissioner of Taxation’s Annual Report for 2002-2003 reported on the broad strategies and results of the ATO’s activities in relation to the legal profession. Generally, the engagement of counsel for the ATO is done through the Australian Government Solicitor, and the ATO would have relied on the AGS’s vetting and selection processes. Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (Question No. 37) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 16 November 2004: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 3582 (Hansard, 5 August 2004, page 32199) why has the Government not made a decision on whether the evaluation of its $9 million media campaign titled ‘Here’s the prescription for a healthy Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme’ would be publicly released.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Brough
theText: The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable mem
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Brough
theText: The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable mem(2) When will a decision be made on whether to publicly release the evaluation report. (3) Will the Government release the evaluation report before 31 March 2005; if not; why not. (1) The evaluation report of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme campaign continues to be an input to policy development and advice from the department and the decision has been made to not release this information at the present stage. (2) The decision whether to publicly release the evaluation report will be periodically reviewed in light of the continuing relevance of the report to policy development and advice. (3) The continuing relevance of the report to policy development and advice will determine whether or not the government decides to release the evaluation report. Association of South-East Asian Nations (Question No. 259 Amended) Mr Beazley asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 2 December 2004: (1) Which clauses of the ANZUS alliance are inconsistent with the ASEAN Treaty of Amity and Cooperation. (2) Which countries which are not members of ASEAN have signed the Treaty. (3) Can he say whether any ASEAN member states or external signatories have (a) criticised Myanmar or other member states for human rights abuses, and (b) commented on a member state’s domestic affairs. (4) Are the terms of the Five Power Defence Arrangement consistent with the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation; if not, what aspects are at variance; if they are consistent, can he explain how the Five Power Defence Arrangement can be consistent with the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation whilst (2) Further to my earlier response to this question, Papua New Guinea, a special observer to ASEAN, has acceded to the Treaty. Air Travel Services (Question No. 410) Mr Quick asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 8 February 2005: (1) Has the Australian Broadcasting Commission issued a tender for the provision of air travel services; if so, when does it close. (2) Does the tender specifically ask tenderers to provide details of Chairman’s Lounge membership free of charge; if so, will Regional Express, Virgin Blue and other domestic carriers which do not normally offer Chairman’s Lounge membership be penalised for not offering it. (3) Does the tender specifically ask tenderers to provide details of upgrades to other classes of travel; if so, will Regional Express, Virgin Blue and other domestic carriers which normally offer only one class of travel be penalised for not offering upgrades to other classes of travel. (4) Will the ABC withdraw its current tender and remove any reference to those aspects of which favour one airline before reissuing it; if not, why not. (5) For the financial years 2002-2003 and 2003-2004, what sum was spent on (a) domestic airline travel, and (b) international airline travel by (i) employees of the ABC, (ii) members of the Board of the ABC, and (iii) ABC contractors.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(6) For the financial years 2002-2003 and 2003-2004, what sum was spent on domestic airline travel on (a) Regional Express, (b) Qantas, and (c) Virgin Blue by (i) employees of the ABC, (ii) members of the Board of the ABC, and (iii) ABC contractors. (7) For the years 2002-2003 and 2003-2004, how many memberships of the (a) Chairman’s Lounge, (b) Qantas Club, (c) Regional Express Club, and (d) Virgin Blue Room, that were paid for by the ABC, were held by (i) employees of the ABC, (ii) members of the Board of the ABC, and (iii) ABC contractors. (8) In respect of each membership in part (7), what was the cost to the ABC of the membership and who received it. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: The ABC has provided the following advice: (1) Yes. The request for tender (RFT) was advertised on 13 November 2004 and closed on 10 December 2004. (2) The RFT asks whether the Chairman’s Lounge membership will be provided free of charge. No tenderer will be penalised for not offering this membership. (3) The RFT specifically asks tenderers to provide details of upgrades to other classes of travel if no seats are available. No tenderer will be penalised if offering only one class of travel. (4) There is no aspect of the RFT which favours one airline above another. The ABC will therefore not be withdrawing the RFT. (5) (a) Domestic airline travel (i) Employees of ABC = $4,504,220 (2002-03); $3,564,132(2003-04) (ii) Members of the Board= $108,587 (2002-03); $77,346 (2003-04) (iii) ABC contractors: these cost would be minimal however, the ABC does not capture them separately and they are included in the above Employee costs. (b) International airline travel (i) Employees of ABC = $2,356,738 (2002-03); $1,688,145 (2003-04) (ii) Members of the Board= $39,169 (2002-03); $31,138 (2003-04) (iii) ABC contractors: these costs would be minimal; however, the ABC does not capture them separately and they are included in the above Employee costs. (6) The ABC is currently in a preferred airline and Travel Management Contract (TMC) with Qantas Business Travel. The ABC does not have records of the travel arranged through the TMC with other carriers. Consequently the figures for 2002-03 are not available. However, in preparation for the RFT, Qantas prepared for the ABC a breakdown by carrier of 2003-04 travel. From these figures, the ABC has calculated the following expenditure with Regional Express, Qantas and Virgin Blue, as shown below: (a) Regional Express (i) Employees of ABC = $51,992. (ii) Members of the Board= Nil. (iii) ABC contractors = these figures are included in Employee figures. (b) Qantas (i) Employees of ABC = $3,226,828.

Life Gold Passes (Question No. 522) Mr Melham asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, in writing, on 8 February 2005: (1) Is the Department of Finance and Administration aware of any travel undertaken during the period 30 December 2002 to 31 December 2004 by any person which was purportedly authorised under the Members of Parliament (Life Gold Pass) Act 2002 when the person was not eligible to undertake such travel at the expense of the Commonwealth. (2) In respect of any travel undertaken at the expense of the Commonwealth which was, but should not have been, approved under the provisions of the Members of Parliament (Life Gold Pass) Act 2002, (a) who was the person or persons who undertook the travel, (b) over what route or routes did the travel take place, (c) what was the cost of the travel, and (d) what action was taken under section 33 of the Act for the recovery of expenses as a debt due to the Commonwealth. ourable member’s question: (1) Yes (2) (a) Hon Tim Fischer AC (b) Albury-Canberra-Albury (c) $426.78 (d) Mr Fischer brought the matter to the attention of the Department of Finance and Administration in a letter dated 31 March 2004, advising that in the course of his visit to Canberra on 29 March 2004 he undertook a commercial activity and enclosed a cheque for $426.78 to cover the cost of the travel. (a) Mrs Julie Reith (b) (1) Melbourne-Cairns-Melbourne (2) Melbourne-Gold Coast-Melbourne (3) Melbourne-Launceston-Melbourne (c) (1) $1,886.67 (2) $565.80 (3) $388.58 (d) The Department of Finance and Administration advised Mr Reith that it had identified travel that appeared to be outside entitlement. Following this advice, Mr Reith reimbursed the Department for the cost of the travel. (a) Hon Dr Alexander Forbes CMG MC (b) Launceston Hobart (c) $117.15 (d) The Department of Finance and Administration identified travel relating to the use of a hire car as being outside entitlement. Dr Forbes has advised that when booking air travel to Tasmania under his Life Gold Pass entitlement, he also requested the travel service provider to arrange a hire car for travel from Launceston to Hobart and for the account for the hire car to be sent to him for payment. The Department was invoiced for both the air travel and the hire car. Dr Forbes reimbursed the Department for the cost of the hire car.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honNaval Communication Station (Question No. 525) Mr Melham asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 8 February 2005: (1) What is the current status of negotiations between the Australian and United States Governments for an agreement relating to the operation of, and access to, the Australian Naval Communication Station (NCS) at North West Cape. (2) When did the current negotiations commence. (3) What level of access by the United States to the NCS is contemplated in the proposed agreement. (4) What is the anticipated duration of the proposed agreement. (5) What contribution will the United States make to operating costs, logistical support and capital upgrades for the NCS at North West Cape. (6) When does the Government expect the new agreement will be finalised. Mrs De-Anne Kelly-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The new Agreement has been agreed by departmental officials at the working level, with the exception of one late addition to the text proposed by Australia, which is now being considered, also at the working level, by the United States (US). (2) 1998. (3) The draft new Agreement provides for the same level of access by the US as provided in the previous agreement. The US will continue to have access to three of the four very low frequency radio communication channels. (4) Twenty-five years, and thereafter for period of five years, unless either party provides notice of termination. (5) The US contributes approximately 75 per cent of the tax-exclusive and excise-exclusive costs of operations, logistical support and capital equipment upgrades. The US does not pay any applicable Australian taxes or excises. (6) The new Agreement is expected to be finalised in late 2005 or early 2006. Women (Question No. 535) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 9 February 2005: (1) What support does the Minister’s department provide to (a) pregnant women and (b) new mothers. (2) Will the Minister require the department to provide further financial and practical support to pregnant women who would otherwise choose an abortion; if so what are the details; if not, why not. (1) (a) Through Medicare, the Department funds a range of prenatal, birth and post natal services. In the case of unplanned pregnancy, the Department funds organisations to provide support, information and non-directive counselling. The Australian Government funds the Australian Federation of Pregnancy Support to provide national sexual and reproductive health counselling services for women requiring support for unplanned pregnancy including a 1300 telephone line and the local services provided by affiliated agencies.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:In addition to the Australian Federation of Pregnancy Support Services, Family Planning Organisations funded under the national family planning program through the Public Health Outcome Funding Agreements also offer pregnancy counselling, both telephone and face to face; website information sheets; interactive facilities; and links to both national and international websites. The Department, through the Office for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health (OATSIH) provides funding to a range of Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Services for the provision of comprehensive primary health care to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, inclusive of a focus on child and maternal health. (b) The Australian Government is currently involved in the development of the National Agenda for Early Childhood (for children 0-5 years, including pregnancy) which is currently being finalised with input from state and territory governments. The National Agenda proposes a broad framework for a national approach to prevention and early intervention with the aim to ensure all children get the best possible start in life. The National Agenda will focus on four broad areas: healthy young families; early learning and care; supporting parents and families; and child-friendly communities. The National Agenda encompasses pregnancy and has a focus on detecting problems early so that appropriate intervention/s can be initiated. Maternal and Child Health is a priority action area identified in the national public health nutrition strategy, Eat Well Australia 2000-2010, endorsed by Australian Health Ministers in 2001. This action area focuses on the promotion of breastfeeding and improving nutrition for pregnant and lactating women, infants and children. The Australian Government acknowledges the important role of breastfeeding in infant nutrition and supports activities to both promote and protect breastfeeding. Activities to promote breastfeeding include: funding the Australian Breastfeeding Association ($100,000 in 2004/05) to promote breastfeeding in the community. The Association fulfils an important role in supporting Australian mothers to establish and maintain breastfeeding; and dissemination of the Australian Dietary Guidelines (NHMRC, 2003). The guidelines aim to provide advice about healthy food choices and lifestyle patterns to promote good nutrition and health for all Australians, including pregnant and lactating women. The recommendations acknowledge the nutritional, health, social and economic benefits of breastfeeding. Activities to protect breastfeeding include: implementing Australia’s response to the World Health Organization Code for the Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes via the Advisory Panel on the Marketing in Australia of Infant Formula (APMAIF). APMAIF is a joint industry-government mechanism for monitoring industry compliance with a self-regulatory agreement that governs the marketing of infant formula in Australia; and administering the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code to protect the quality, safety and labelling aspects of infant formula. The Government’s 2004 Election policy included a commitment to provide further funding of $30 million over four years to Beyondblue, the National Depression Initiative. Beyondblue has a program which focuses on post natal depression. (2) It is the role of the Department of Family and Community Services and the Department of Human Services to provide practical and financial support to pregnant women and/or new mothers. This includes, for example, the parenting payment, maternity payment and other related family assistance payments. The Department of Health and Aging provides subsidies to the Australian public through the Medicare Benefits Schedule and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme for medical and pharmaceutical services. Women (Question No. 536) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 9 February 2005: (1) What support does the Minister’s department provide to (a) pregnant women and (b) new mothers. (2) Will the Minister require the department to provide further financial and practical support to pregnant women who would otherwise choose an abortion; if so, what are the details; if not, why not. ing answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The Government, through the Department of Family and Community Services (FaCS), provides a range of payments and services to support pregnant women and new mothers. The Government provides a range of family assistance including Maternity Payment, Maternity Immunisation Allowance, Family Tax Benefit (FTB) PartA and FTB Part B. Additionally, from 1 July 2005, mothers returning to work after the birth of a child will be assisted by the quarantining of FTB PartB payments. This means the income they earn after returning to work will not affect the FTB PartB received earlier in that financial year. FaCS also supports new mothers by providing support for child care. Principally, this assistance is in the form of Child Care Benefit (CCB), a means tested payment made to families to assist with the costs of child care. CCB is available for families using approved child care services or registered carers. In addition to the financial support available through the Child Care Benefit, the Government announced in the election context that a 30 per cent Child Care Tax Rebate would be implemented. The Child Care Tax Rebate will cover 30 per cent of out-of-pocket expenses, that is, regular fees for approved care, less CCB entitlement, for families who receive CCB and meet the CCB work/study/training test. The Child Care Tax Rebate will be payable on costs from 1 July 2004, and will be payable up to a maximum of $4,000 per child per year. The Child Care Tax Rebate is payable in addition to any CCB entitlement. The Australian Government Jobs Education and Training (JET) Child Care supports JET creches, which are flexible and innovative services that enable parents to participate in training and work activities in areas where no other suitable child care services are available, or where it is deemed in the best interests of the child and parent to remain in close proximity. JET creches are run in conjunction with education and training activities for targeted vulnerable groups such as teenage parents. Creches enable parents to attend their courses while their children receive care on-site or nearby. There are a number of creches attached to high schools to support young teenage mothers. In 2004-05, 75 JET creches have been funded across the five states and territories of WA, SA, NT, NSW and QLD. The total funding for JET Child Care creches in 2004-05 is approximately $4 million. The Stronger Families and Communities Strategy provides support through a number of projects which help pregnant women and new mothers. The Strategy focuses on the Government’s concerns
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Hockey
theText: The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the followabout the health, development and well-being of Australian children with a focus on children from 0-5 years. The Government has committed nearly $490 million to the Strategy over the next four years. The Strategy consists of four main streams: Communities for Children ($142.4 million over four years) targets up to 45 disadvantaged communities providing funding for local early childhood initiatives; Early Childhood – Invest to Grow ($70.5 million over four years) provides funding for national early childhood programs and resources. It will ensure that Australia continues to be one of the world leaders in best practice in the early childhood development arena; Local Answers ($137 million over four years) gives communities the power to develop their own solutions and help them help themselves by supporting locally developed and implemented projects which provide help in such areas as parenting and relationship skills, community strengthening and participation for young parents, volunteering, mentoring and leadership; and Choice and Flexibility in Child Care ($125.3 million over four years) continues the groundbreaking work of the first Strategy in providing Australian parents with flexible and innovative child care solutions. It will fund the continuation of the in-home care program and provide additional places for families without other formal child care options. There will be incentives for long day care providers to set up in areas of high need, and funding will continue to the quality assurance systems for family day care and outside school hours care. From the Prime Minister’s announcement in April 2004 to 1 March 2005, 21 projects were approved for funding which provide support to pregnant women and young mothers under the Local Answers initiative of the Strategy at a total of some $4.3 million. The Department also supports pregnant women and young mothers through programs such as Early Childhood-Invest to Grow and Responding Early Assisting Children (REACh). REACh aims to improve the capacity of parents and other caregivers to respond appropriately to children’s needs for care, stimulation and safety. It encourages early intervention approaches to prevent child abuse, neglect and other poor outcomes for children. Early Childhood-Invest to Grow funds projects that provide targeted early intervention and prevention projects in various areas of Australia. These include: home visiting; parenting education and workshops; family therapy and support for families of children with a disability; education and support for mothers with intellectual disability; and advice for new mothers about available services. Funded projects also include development of resources or tools for use by parents, professionals and the community to support positive early childhood development. These include the $4 million Parenting Information Website, which will shortly commence development. Most recently, the Government announced a grant of $615,000 under the Early Childhood – Invest To Grow program to help expand nationally the Core of Life ‘Pregnancy, Birth, Breastfeeding and Early Parenting’ Program to address the rate of teenage pregnancies. The Family Relationships Services Program (FRSP) provides funding to 100 community organisations to deliver family relationships services through about 350 outlets across Australia. The program’s current aims are to enable children, young people and adults in all their diversity to develop and sustain safe, supportive and nurturing family relationships; and to minimise the emotional, social and economic costs associated with disruption to family relationships. (2) Practical support for women around reproductive choices is the primary responsibility of the States and Territories, with some support also provided by the Australian Government, including that outlined in answer (1). Battle of Long Tan (Question No. 539) Mr Bevis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 9 February 2005: (1) In respect of Australian veterans at the Battle of Long Tan in the Vietnam War, can the Minister confirm that all Australians who were awarded an individual citation from the then Government of the Republic of Vietnam have been given permission to wear them. (2) Has the Government also authorised the wearing, by Australian veterans, of unit citations and awards provided by the then Government of the Republic of Vietnam; if so, when; if not, why not. Mrs De-Anne Kelly-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) No. The Government is unable to confirm that all Australian veterans of the Battle of Long Tan who were awarded individual citations and awards by the then Government of the Republic of Vietnam have permission to wear them. Each veteran has to apply to the Australian Government to have individual citations and awards formally approved for wearing. (2) Yes. At the time of the Vietnam War, the Government accepted an offer and approved the wearing of a Cross of Gallantry Unit Citation for the following three units: Australian Army Training Team Vietnam (1970); 8th Battalion the Royal Australian Regiment (1970); and No2 Squadron RAAF (1970). Job Network Providers (Question No. 556) Ms King asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 10 February 2005: (1) How many Job Network providers are currently operating in the electoral division of Ballarat and what are their names and addresses. (2) How many job seekers are currently registered with (a) each Job Network provider and (b) each office of each provider operating in the electoral division of Ballarat. (3) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, in (i) Australia and (ii) the electoral division of Ballarat, how many Newstart or Youth Allowance recipients were placed into jobs through assistance from Job Network providers. (4) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many long-term unemployed people (i) in total, and (ii) as a proportion of all unemployed people, participated in intensive assistance programs in the electoral division of Ballarat. (5) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many of the people who have participated in intensive assistance in the electoral division of Ballarat have participated on (i) one occasion, (ii) two occasions, (iii) three occasions, and (iv) more than three occasions. (6) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many job seekers who participated in intensive assistance in the electoral division of Ballarat found employment and what proportion found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time, and (iii) casual employment. (7) How many Work for the Dole providers are currently operating in the electoral division of Ballarat, what are their names and addresses and what programs do they offer. (8) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Ballarat found employment. (9) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, what proportion of people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Ballarat found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time, and (iii) casual employment following their placement. (10) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Ballarat were in (i) full-time, (ii) part-time, (iii) casual employment three months after completing their placement. (1) and (2) Job Network is administered on the basis of 19 Labour Market Regions and 137 Employment Services Areas (ESAs), the boundaries of which do not align with those of Federal Electorates. Job seekers choose Job Network members for a variety of reasons including location, proximity to transport routes and Centrelink offices, or the satisfaction of friends and others. Job seekers residing in one Electorate or ESA may be assisted through Job Network sites located in adjoining Electorates or ESAs. For illustration, job seekers residing in the Electorate of Ballarat may be assisted through Job Network sites located in the Electorates of Bendigo, McEwen or Lalor. The Eureka ESA is most closely aligned with the Electorate of Ballarat and, therefore, answers are provided with reference to this ESA. There are currently 18 Job Network members and other Job Placement Organisations operating in the Eureka ESA. Their names, office locations and the number of job seekers on their caseloads are shown in Table 1. Shark Fishery (Question No. 567) Mr Albanese asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 14 February 2005: (1) In respect of the anti-finning regulations in the Northern Territory Joint Authority Shark Fishery, how and where are the shark trunks being landed at the Port of Darwin being disposed of. (2) What records are available in respect of shark trunk disposal. (3) How is compliance with the anti-finning regulations being determined. (4) To what extent are shark trunks still being discarded at sea. (5) What is the level of compliance investment and presence in the Northern Territory Shark Fishery. (6) What level of training in fisheries compliance is given to the compliance officers and can he confirm that the compliance officers are members of the Northern Territory police force. (1) Shark trunks are being sold to local, national and international markets. Product uses include fresh and frozen fillets for human consumption, fish emulsion and they are internationally processed into seafood balls, tempura and soups for human consumption.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Truss
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) All shark product weights and cuts are recorded by fishers in monthly market logbooks at the point of sale and comparisons are made with logbook returns from Traders/Processors to validate monthly returns from individual fishers. (3) Random on board vessel inspections are made by Northern Territory Fisheries Police officers to ensure compliance with gear and fin ratio regulations. The Fisheries Group of the Northern Territory Department of Business, Industry and Resource Development also holds annual fin ratio review workshops with industry and compulsory logbook returns are analysed regularly. (4) Shark trunks are not being dumped at sea. Fishers are required to land a prescribed amount of meat with every fin landed (fin ratios). In addition, recent licence conditions prevent shark meat from leaving port again on board a vessel. (5) There are 17 dedicated Fisheries Police members in the Police Marine Enforcement Section of the Northern Territory Police Force. In 2004, 47 random compliance checks were made on vessels operating in the Northern Territory shark fishery. (6) Officers of the dedicated marine police section are fully trained and endorsed Northern Territory Police officers. Asylum Seekers (Question No. 581) Ms Hoare asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 14 February 2005: (1) How many asylum seekers from tsunami affected countries are (a) being held in detention; and (b) on temporary protection visas (TPVs). (2) Will the Government urgently review the applications for permanent protection for those asylum seekers from tsunami affected countries. (3) Has the Minister’s department been approached by any asylum seekers from tsunami affected countries requesting assistance relating to the welfare of their families in tsunami affected areas; if so, (a) how many; and (b) is the Minister able to assist those families; if so, how. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (a) Departmental systems indicate that, as at 11 February 2005, there was one protection visa applicant from a tsunami affected country who was in detention. This person’s application was recently remitted to the Department by the Refugee Review Tribunal. Further checks are being undertaken in order to decide the visa application. (b) Departmental systems indicate that as at 11 February 2005, there were some 90 remaining temporary protection visa holders from tsunami affected countries. (2) Applications for further protection visas lodged by temporary protection visa holders from tsunami affected countries are being assessed on their merits under the normal arrangements for determining applications for further protection visas. To be eligible for grant of a further protection visa, an applicant must either be found to be owed protection obligations under the Refugees Convention or be accompanying a family member who has been found to be owed such protection obligations. The tsunami and the damage and disruption it has caused do not meet the grounds set out in the Refugees Convention for identifying persons owed refugee protection. However, where the Refugee Review Tribunal affirms a decision to refuse a further protection visa, the Minister has a noncompellable personal power to substitute for the Tribunal decision a decision which is more favourable to the applicant, where the Minister considers this to be in the public interest.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs(3) (a) An emergency Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) hotline commenced operating from 30 December 2004 to provide advice on visa arrangements for Australian citizens and residents with relatives in tsunami-affected areas and foreign nationals from affected areas temporarily in Australia. As at 9 February 2005, some 900 calls had been received by DIMIA from persons seeking advice on visa arrangements for Australian citizens and residents with relatives in tsunamiaffected areas and foreign nationals from affected areas temporarily in Australia. The hotline was discontinued on 18 February 2005 due to the diminishing number of calls. fected countries. (b) My Department is maintaining communication with relevant migrant communities in Australia, including monitoring the needs of those whose relatives are missing or have been killed or injured. Concerns by immigration detainees about the welfare of family members in affected areas have been addressed by providing access to overseas phones calls and through tracing assistance from the Australian Red Cross. It is not possible to identify the extent to which the calls were from asylum seekers from tsunami affected countries requesting assistance relating to the welfare of their families in tsunami affected areas. Immigration Removals (Question No. 595) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 16 February 2005: (1) Can he confirm the report in The Age on 28 January which stated that a person accompanied by three security guards on a Thai Airlines flight had been chained by the hands and feet and had gaffer tape around his head covering his mouth; if so, were these actions taken by the Australia Government and, if they were, why. (2) How was this passenger able to eat, drink or go to the toilet. (3) Have there been other instances of people being transported under similar conditions; if so, how many. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: I am advised that: (1) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) was responsible for the removal of this person as he had no entitlement to remain in Australia. In exceptional circumstances the use of restraint on high risk removees during a removal operation may be required. This includes cases where the removee presents a high security risk or behaves in a way that threatens the safety of themself or others. In this case, the removee was violent, noisy and disruptive during the removal process. He assaulted the escorts and attempted to bite them. He also bit his own lips, apparently in an attempt to delay his removal and appear unfit to travel. The escorting officers found that it was necessary to restrain the person with hand restraints, leg restraints and mouth tape, to allow him to board the flight without posing further danger to himself or others. (2) The removee was restrained for the minimum time required. The flight departed Sydney with a stopover in Melbourne. The restraints were removed when the flight departed Melbourne on its international leg. The removee was allowed to eat and drink. He was also allowed toilet breaks.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs(3) During the period July 2003 – June 2004 there were 10 reported incidents of removees being restrained with hand and leg restraints. In addition, five were restrained by the hands only. During the period July 2004 – February 2005 there were 11 reported incidents of removees restrained with hand and leg restraints. Four of these 11 removees were additionally restrained with mouth tape. In once instance it was also necessary to tape a removee’s finger nails due to attempts in the past to use them as an instrument to harm himself and others. Commercial Agreements (Question No. 601) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 16 February 2005: (1) Has the Minister read the article titled ‘When the journalist is a party spin doctor, it’s bad PR for real news’ in the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 February 2005. (2) In respect of those parts of the report that say “In shades of Australia’s cash-for-comment scandal, a conservative syndicated US columnist and pundit has been secretly contracted for $307,000 by the Bush Administration to promote the President’s education policies in his columns and TV appearances” and “it is no longer clear who is and who isn’t a journalist in the US”, can the Minister guarantee that the Australian Government has not entered into any similar agreement with a journalist or commentator in Australia; if not, why not. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Yes. (2) My Portfolio does not have a whole of Government responsibility for this issue. Disclosure of commercial arrangements between radio current affairs presenters and sponsors is provided for by the Broadcasting Services (Commercial Radio Current Affairs Disclosure) Standard 2000. The standard requires on-air disclosure during current affairs programs of commercial agreements between sponsors and presenters that have the potential to affect the content of those programs. Commercial radio licensees are also required to provide the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) with particulars of each commercial agreement between sponsors and presenters of current affairs programs or their associates. This register is published on the website of the ABA. Licensees are also required to publish these details on any website operated by or on behalf of the licensee. Compliance with the Standard is a condition of a broadcaster’s licence. The Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice also provides for the disclosure of commercial arrangements. The Code requires the disclosure, by licensees, of any agreements or arrangements under which a licensee, an independent producer or a presenter agrees with a third party to endorse or feature the third party’s products or services in a factual program in exchange for consideration. The disclosure must be made either during the program or in the credits of the program and should adequately bring the existence of any such commercial arrangement to the attention of viewers in a way that is readily understandable to a reasonable person. It should be noted that my Portfolio responsibilities for media issues in Australia do not include the operation of the print media. Any concerns the honourable member may have regarding the impact of commercial agreements on the representation of news and current affairs in the print media should be directed to the Australian Press Council (APC).
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the ArtsMedical Board of Inquiry (Question No. 615) Mr Bevis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 17 February 2005: (1) In respect of the findings of the WA. Medical Board of Inquiry against Dr McKenzie, did Dr McKenzie pay the fine of $10,000 imposed on him or was it paid by Defence. (2) Did the WA. Board order Dr McKenzie to pay 75% of the Board’s legal costs; if so, (a) what was that sum and (b) what proportion of that sum was paid by Defence. (3) Did the legal firm, Phillips Fox, bill Defence for 1,178.5 hours of its services in defending Dr McKenzie; if so, what was that sum. (4) Is the Minister able to say what costs were incurred by the female officer who was the victim in this case. (5) Has Defence met any of the costs incurred by the victim in this case; if so, what sum; if not, why not. Mrs De-Anne Kelly-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Defence did not pay the fine. (2) Yes. (a) $75,000. (b) 80 per cent of the amount payable by Dr McKenzie. (3) Defence was billed for 1,178.6 hours (the previous figure of 1,178.5 hours stated by Defence was a typographical error). The sum was $377,221.28 for legal costs, including Counsel’s fees, for representing Dr McKenzie. (4) No. (5) No. The requests for assistance made by that person have not been considered to be within the assistance provisions set out in the Attorney-General’s Legal Services Directions. Fighter Aircraft (Question No. 617) Mr Bevis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 17 February 2005: (1) Does the Government intend to proceed with the purchase of the F-35; if so, (a) when will the first F-35s arrive and (b) how many will arrive in the first delivery. (2) Will the F-35s be delivered progressively over the two-year period or will they all arrive together at some point within the two-year period. (3) When is it planned to withdraw the F-111s from service. (4) When is it planned to withdraw the F/A-18 Hornets from service. (5) What contingency plans have been made in case the delivery of the F-35 is delayed. Mrs De-Anne Kelly-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The Government has not yet made a formal decision to purchase the Joint Strike Fighter. (2) Presuming a decision to acquire the aircraft, delivery for the first two phases of Air 6000 (Phases 2A/B) is expected to occur over about a five-year period from 2012. (3) Around 2010. (4) The nominal withdrawal date for the F/A-18 Hornet is 2015. The eventual withdrawal date of the last F/A-18s will be determined in conjunction with determining the optimum delivery profile of the Joint Strike Fighter. (5) The structural life of the F/A-18 is being extended as part of the Hornet Upgrade Program. F111 Aircraft (Question No. 621) Mr Bevis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 17 February 2005: (1) In respect of the compensation to be paid to those affected by the F-111 Deseal/Reseal process, how is the value of compensation for each applicant to be determined. (2) When will each of the applicants be advised of the procedure of applying for compensation. (3) When will compensation be paid. (4) Is the payment to each applicant contingent on no further legal action being taken on the part of the applicant. Mrs De-Anne Kelly-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: Decisions on the amount of lump sum payments for those affected by the F-111 Deseal/Reseal programs and arrangements to give effect to the lump sum payments scheme are still being considered. Hillsong Foundation and Associated Entities (Question No. 634) Dr Lawrence asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 7 March 2005: For each of the last five years, what are the details and sum of each grant and service payment by the Minister’s department and agencies within the Minister’s portfolio to (a) the Hillsong Foundation, and (b) its associated entities. The Department has reviewed its financial records and contacted agencies, and has concluded that no payments have been made to either the Hillsong Foundation, or its associated entities. Hillsong Foundation and Associated Entities (Question No. 637) Dr Lawrence asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, in writing, on 7 March 2005: For each of the last five years, what are the details and sum of each grant and service payment by the Minister’s department and agencies within the Minister’s portfolio to (a) the Hillsong Foundation, and (b) its associated entities. swer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (a) and (b) Nil.

speaker: Mr Truss
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Truss
theText: The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following anCapitaine Tasman (Question No. 645) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, in writing, on 7 March 2005: (1) In respect of the vessel Capitaine Tasman (IMO Number 9210725), (a) has it ever operated in Australian waters under a single or continuous voyage permit; if so, when, (b) does it operate a regular service through Australian ports, (c) does it have an approved security plan which complies with the International Ship and Port Facility Code (ISPS), (d) has the Office of Transport Security ever had any concerns in relation to the security of this vessel, and (e) has it ever been boarded and inspected by the (i) Office of Transport Security and (ii) AMSA officials; if so, when. (2) Was the Office of Transport Security aware that the crew of this vessel was denied access to shore leave when the ship arrived in Australia on 17 February 2005. (3) Can he confirm that the denial of shore leave for the crew of this vessel was a breach of Australia’s obligations under the ISPS. (4) Was the denial of shore leave in any way related to security concerns in respect of (a) the vessel and (b) any of the crew. (5) Is the Office of Transport Security aware of any current security alerts regarding the ISPS for ports in Fiji. (1) (a) My Department’s records indicate that coasting trade permits were held by the Capitaine Tasman in the period July 2000 to June 2001. (b) Published information indicates that the Capitaine Tasman is part of a regular liner cargo shipping service through Australian ports. (c) According to the available records the vessel has a current International Ship Security Certificate and therefore would have a ship security plan registered with its Flag state. (d) The OTS Operations Centre has security compliance assessed this vessel on nine occasions; 04.7.2004, 26.7.2004, 31.8.2004, 17.9.2004, 06.12.2004, 3.11.2004, 06.1.2005, 14.2.2005, 15.3.2005. The assessments raised no security concerns. (e) (i) The OTS Operations Centre has not issued any Maritime Security Tasking Requests to inspect this vessel. (ii) AMSA records inspections of the ship on the following dates: 4.1.2002, 22.2.2002, 27.3.2002, 6.4.2002, 26.4.2002, 25.6.2002, 24.7.2002, 25.9.2002, 27.11.2002, 25.3.2003, 29.5.2003, 26.9.2003, 27.11.2003, 2.4.2004, 4.10.2004, 7.10.2004 and 8.11.2004. (2) On 17.2.2005, the OTS’s Operations Centre received a call from an Australian representative from the International Transport Federation. The caller was querying as to why crew had been restricted on board the vessel on 16.2.2005 at the port of Brisbane. (3) The ISPS Code provides that security plans must address procedures for facilitating shore leave for ships’ personnel. It does not guarantee it. All security plans approved by the Australian Government meet this requirement of the ISPS Code. (4) (a) No. (b) The denial of shore leave was a decision made by DIMIA under the Migration Act. (5) OTS is not aware of any current security alerts regarding the ISPS Code for Fijian ports.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Australian Broadcasting Authority (Question No. 650) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 7 March 2005: (1) When did the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) first form the view that an additional widecoverage community radio service should be made available in Sydney. (2) When did the ABA decide to make the 1386 AM radio frequency available in Sydney for a community broadcasting service instead of a narrowcasting service. (3) Why did the ABA (a) reject all eight applications for the 1386 AM radio frequency in Sydney in March 2003, (b) deny the grant of a temporary radio licence, and (c) call for another round of public comment on or about 22 April 2004. (4) What is the current status of the granting of a radio licence for the 1386 AM frequency. (5) Will a licence for the 1386 AM frequency be granted; if so, when; if not, why not. (6) Can the Minister confirm that Sydney Christian Broadcasters Ltd, known as Radio Rhema, was one of the applicants when the ABA called for applications for the 1386 AM frequency for a community radio station in March 2003; if so, can the Minister also confirm that it demonstrated the highest public interest submission, presenting a membership of some 4,000 persons with over 750 letters in support and representing close to 460,000 persons in the greater Sydney region. (7) Will the Minister take action to ensure that no further delay occurs in the granting of a Sydney community radio licence on the 1386 AM frequency; if so, what action; if not, why not. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) At the time that the ABA released its report on the allocation of three community radio broadcasting licences for Sydney, it advised in a news release on 25 May 2001 that it had formed a preliminary view that an additional wide coverage community radio service should be made available in Sydney. (2) On 24 May 2001, the ABA released a discussion paper and a proposed variation to the Sydney Licence Area Plan which considered the option that another community radio broadcasting service to serve Sydney be made available for allocation, operating on the 1386 kHz frequency. I am advised that after considering the submissions received, the ABA decided to approve the variation to the Sydney Licence Area Plan on 28 March 2002, making an additional community radio broadcasting service available for allocation for the Sydney licence area operating on 1386 kHz. (3) (a) to (c) The ABA has advised that: On 27 February 2003, after carefully assessing the applications received the ABA decided not to allocate the licence as it considered that no applicant had adequately demonstrated that it could satisfy all of the criteria at section 84(2) of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. On 27 February 2003 the ABA decided not to make the 1386 kHz frequency available for temporary community broadcasting due to problems that had recently been identified in relation to serious electro-magnetic compatibility and possible health and safety issues due to the location of the transmission tower at the nominal transmission site at Homebush Bay and its proximity to new residential areas. The ABA advised that it would review this situation in 12 months time. In its 10 May 2004 news release, the ABA announced the commencement of its review to explore the issues surrounding the use of the 1386 kHz frequency in Sydney and possible options for its future use in the Sydney licence area. Written submissions were sought from the public in relation to the matters raised in the paper.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts(4) I am advised that the ABA has not made a decision regarding the future use of the 1386 kHz frequency for the Sydney licence area. This decision has been deferred until such time as the Government digital radio policy is further developed. (5) See answer to Part (4). (6) I am advised that Sydney Christian Broadcasters Ltd (Rhema Sydney) was one of eight applicants for the community radio broadcasting licence to operate on the 1386 kHz frequency. At the time of submitting its application, Rhema Sydney stated that it had over 4,249 financial members, provided petitions and letters of support with over 7,500 signatories and provided over 500 letters of support from churches. Rhema quoted a 1998 Australian Community Survey that indicated that 20% of the Christian population (476,000 people in Sydney) attended a church on a monthly basis. It claimed a target audience of between 237,000 and 755,000 people; however, did not provide evidence to support this. It should also be noted that there is already a community radio broadcasting service licensed in Sydney to serve this Christian community. (7) The allocation of licences for community radio broadcasting is a matter for the ABA. The ABA indicated in its 10 May 2004 news release that it is considering a range of options for the use of the frequency including retaining it for a community service, making it available for an open narrowcasting service, using it for Digital Radio Mondiale trials or making it available for other purposes. The ABA is required to consider the appropriate use of the 1386 kHz frequency for Sydney in a manner consistent with the objectives of the Act. Wollongong Hospital (Question No. 656) Ms Bird asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 7 March 2005: (1) Is he aware of the community campaign in Wollongong to have the Government allocate an MRI licence to Wollongong Hospital. (2) Will he list the occasions his office and department have communicated with constituents and community groups in the electoral division of (a) Cunningham and (b) Throsby, including details of the identity of the correspondent and the date and mode of correspondence (ie letter, facsimile, and email), concerning the allocation of an MRI licence to Wollongong Hospital. (1) I am aware of the community campaign in Wollongong to extend Medicare eligibility to the MRI unit at Wollongong Hospital. (2) My Office and my Department have responded to many representations from constituents and community groups regarding the extension of Medicare eligibility to the MRI unit at the Wollongong Hospital. For privacy reasons, I do not feel that it is appropriate to list every such communication. I should point out that there is a Medicare eligible MRI machine within Wollongong located less than 500 metres from the hospital and that the state government is responsible for the provision of MRI services to public patients in public hospitals. Broadband Services (Question No. 658) Ms Bird asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 7 March 2005: (1) Is it the case that Broadband service is not available in all areas of the electoral division of Cunningham; if so, which areas do not have access to Broadband.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) What reasons does Telstra give for not providing access to Broadband. (3) What action is Telstra taking to address this situation. (4) Is the Minister able to say when Broadband services will be available throughout the electoral division of Cunningham. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question based largely on advice from Telstra: (1) No, it is not the case. Broadband services are available in all areas of the electoral division of Cunningham through a variety of technology platforms including Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL), CDMA EVDO and other wireless broadband technologies, one way satellite and two way satellite. There are a number of service providers operating infrastructure to delivers broadband services in the electoral division of Cunningham, including Telstra, Fish Internet, Australian Private Networks, Clear Networks and NewSat. The Australian Government’s Higher Bandwidth Incentive Scheme is providing financial assistance to service providers to enable them to supply services at metropolitan comparable prices to eligible customers within the non-metropolitan parts of the electoral division of Cunningham. (2) See answer to Part (1). (3) See answer to Part (1). (4) See answer to Part (1). Joint Offshore Protection Command (Question No. 664) writing, on 7 March 2005: When the Joint Offshore Protection Command is established, will it exercise any powers other than those that existed prior to its establishment under Customs legislation or Defence legislation. the honourable member’s question: The JOPC is not charged with the enforcement of any specific legislation. Its purpose is to strengthen planning, and command and control arrangements for military offshore maritime protection functions and civil maritime surveillance and response. Joint Offshore Protection Command (Question No. 670) writing, on 7 March 2005: (1) Prior to the establishment of the Joint Offshore Protection Command (JOPC), under what power, legislative or otherwise, does the Australian Customs Service (ACS) have authority to order a vessel within the 1000 nautical mile ‘Australian Maritime Information zone’ to report the contents of its cargo. (2) When the JOPC is established, under what power, legislative or otherwise, will it have authority to order vessels within the 1000 nautical mile ‘Australian Maritime Information zone’ to report to the ACS the contents of its cargo.
