title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister Representing The Minister For Justice And Customs, In
theText: (3) Prior to the establishment of the JOPC, what is the jurisdictional limit (in nautical miles) from the coast of the Australian mainland or an Australian Territory for an ACS officer to intercept, board and/or search a vessel and what is the legislative basis for these powers. (4) When the JOPC is established, what will be the jurisdictional limit (in nautical miles) from the coast of the Australian mainland or any Australian Territory for an ACS officer to intercept, board and/or search a vessel and what will be the legislative basis for these powers. (5) Has the ACS (a) requested and (b) received any legal advice concerning the ability of the JOPC to order the interdiction of any vessel within the 1000 nautical mile ‘Australian Maritime Information zone’; if so, when was the legal advice (i) sought and (ii) received and (iii) what was the nature of the advice. (6) Can the Minister confirm that the proposed 1000 nautical mile reporting zone extends five times further than Australia’s existing maritime boundary-the 200nm Exclusive Economic Zone-and overlaps the maritime jurisdiction of Indonesia and New Zealand; if so, what is the legal basis for requiring vessels to report within these areas. (7) Will the head of the JOPC have authority to make orders and give directions to (a) Australian Customs Service vessels and (b) Australian Defence vessels. (8) What is the extent of the head of the JOPC’s powers, in particular, will he or she have authority to direct the crew of a (a) Navy and (b) ACS vessel to (i) interdict a vessel, (ii) board a vessel, and (iii) exercise lethal force. (9) What legislation will the JOPC be responsible for enforcing and will that legislation give the JOPC authority to (a) interdict vessels, (b) board vessels, and (c) exercise coercive force. (10) What assets will be available to the JOPC, in particular, (a) how many vessels, (b) how many aircraft and (c) what other infrastructure. (11) Will the JOPC have a role in terms of future strategic planning in respect of border protection and in particular in respect of decisions regarding the future acquisition and use of assets; if so, what. the honourable member’s question: (1) Section 64AB of the Customs Act 1901 provides the legislative basis for cargo reporting. Subsection 64AB (8) relevantly states that: A cargo report is to be made not later than: (a) if the cargo is carried on a ship: (i) the start of a prescribed period; or (ii) if the journey from the last port is of a kind described in regulations made for the purpose of this subparagraph-the start of the shorter period that is specified in those regulations; before the estimated time of arrival of the ship at the first port in Australia since it last departed from a port outside Australia. Currently, the prescribed period for reporting is 48 hours unless the journey from the last port departed outside Australia is likely to take less than 48 hours, then not later than 24 hours before its arrival is the prescribed period. No journey’s have been prescribed. (2) When the JOPC is fully established, only vessels proposing to enter Australian ports will be required to provide details of their cargo, as currently required by section 64AB of the Customs Act 1901. (3) Sections 184A to 185AB provide the legislative basis to board and/or search certain foreign and Australian vessels.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer toThe jurisdiction with respect to Australian ships is based on international law under which States can exercise jurisdiction over their own vessels provided those vessels are not located in the territorial sea of another State. The jurisdiction with respect to foreign ships falls variously within 12 nautical miles, 24 nautical miles and 200 nautical miles. Australia has sovereignty within the 12 nautical mile territorial sea claimed by Proclamation in the Gazette No. S 297, 1990, under section 7 of the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973. Therefore, Customs enforces a range of Commonwealth laws. The jurisdiction with respect to foreign ships between 12 nautical miles and 24 nautical miles is limited to establishing the identity of a ship or, the prevention or punishment of a contravention or an attempted contravention in Australia of the Customs Act 1901 or an Act prescribed by regulations consistently with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). The Acts prescribed are the Migration Act 1958, Quarantine Act 1908, Fisheries Management Act 1991 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1984. The jurisdiction with respect to foreign ships between 12 nautical miles and 200 nautical miles is the exercise of board and/or search powers where there is a suspicion that that the vessel is, will be or has been involved in a contravention, or attempted contravention, in Australia’s Exclusive Economic Zone of the Fisheries Management Act 1991. Generally states do not have jurisdiction over foreign ships on the high seas. There are three exceptions to this that allow a boarding to be made and powers to be exercised over foreign ships. The first exception is where an agreement exists between Australia and the flag state of the foreign ship. No such agreements are currently in place. The second exception is to board a ship without nationality to establish the ship’s identity. The third exception is exercising powers over a mother ship that may be on the high seas. That is, although the mother ship is located on the high seas it is linked to a ship closer to Australia (daughter ship) and the two ships are involved in a contravention of Australian law. (4) As above. (5) (a) No. (b) No. (6) The Australian Maritime Identification System (AMIS) is not a reporting zone. At this stage there are no new reporting requirements proposed under the AMIS. (7) (a) Yes, when Australian Customs Vessels are assigned under operational control to the Commander JOPC for specific operations. (b) Yes, when the ADF vessels are assigned under operational control to the Commander JOPC for specific operations. (8) For military operations and combined exercises, the Chief of Defence Force (CDF) will assign ADF forces to the Chief of Joint Operations (CJOPS). Within any constraints imposed by CDF, the commander of an operation or exercise. For the conduct of civil and Customs operations and joint/combined exercises, the Chief Executive Officer Australian Customs Service (CEO Customs) will assign airborne surveillance assets, and may direct other assets such as Australian Customs Vessels, to the Commander JOPC for his/her control and management for specific operations or exercises. The Commander JOPC will issue orders that accord with the Rules of Engagement (ROE) promulgated by CDF through CJOPS and by the CEO Customs. (9) JOPC is not charged with the enforcement of any specific legislation. Its purpose is to simplify and strengthen planning, as well as command and control arrangements for military offshore maritime protection functions and the conduct of civil maritime surveillance. (10) There are 8 Australian Customs Vessels; 17 Coastwatch aircraft; 15 Navy Fremantle Class Patrol Boats and 12 Navy Armidale Patrol Boats yet to be delivered. In September 2004 Government announced the acquisition of an additional two Armidale Class patrol boats. The number assigned to JOPC will vary depending on Customs and Defence tasking priorities and requirements. (11) The JOPC will contribute to future strategic planning, particularly in respect to the counterterrorism aspects of border protection. It is also anticipated that JOPC will have input in respect of decisions regarding the acquisition and use of assets, although JOPC will not own any of the particular assets. It is intended that JOPC will use Customs and ADF assets to execute a particular operation during a particular period and at the end of that operation, hand back control of the asset. Australian Federal Police (Question No. 678) writing, on 7 March 2005: (1) How many Australian Federal Police (AFP) officers are based at the AFP station in the Torres Strait. (2) How many AFP officers are currently assigned to conduct joint patrols to combat transnational crime between PNG and Australia. (3) Does the AFP plan to introduce any other measures to combat the drug trade between PNG and Australia. the honourable member’s question: (1) There are two AFP employees based full time on Thursday Island, with additional support provided by the AFP’s Cairns Office as required. (2) The AFP in North Queensland participates with State and Commonwealth agencies in all joint cross border-patrols between Australia and PNG. The number of AFP members deployed varies in proportion to the circumstances and the objectives of the patrol. (3) The AFP is working closely with State and Commonwealth agencies at both a tactical and strategic level to counteract the illicit drug trade between Australia and PNG. On available evidence, current strategies are sufficient and effective, however operational and intelligence practices targeting illicit drug activity in the Torres Strait are monitored and reviewed as required. Australian Federal Police (Question No. 679) writing, on 7 March 2005: (1) What measures, procedures or policies does the Australian Federal Police (AFP) have in place to replace the occupants of the positions held by AFP officers in Australia prior to their deployment overseas. (2) What tasks, activities or positions have AFP officers been removed from prior to their deployment to Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands. (3) Do any of these tasks, activities or positions presently remain unfilled; if so, which ones.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister Representing The Minister For Justice And Customs, In
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister Representing The Minister For Justice And Customs, In
theText: (4) What procedures are there to assist with the transition of files and/or investigations from an AFP officer who is being deployed overseas to the AFP officer assuming responsibility for that file or investigation. (5) Have any files and or investigations been left in abeyance as a result of overseas deployments. (6) Has the AFP conducted an inquiry or requested a report on the effect of the deployment of AFP officers overseas on the ability of the AFP to deliver key capabilities in Australia; if so, what are the details and the findings. (7) Does the AFP intend to conduct an inquiry or has the AFP requested a report on the effect of the deployment of AFP officers overseas on the ability of the AFP to deliver key capabilities in Australia; if so, when; if not, why not. the honourable member’s question: The AFP has a sophisticated and pre-existing methodology for accepting, allocating and monitoring matters referred to it for investigation. In considering acceptance or rejection of referrals the AFP applies its Case Categorisation & Prioritisation Model (CCPM). Decisions to accept or reject a referral take into account a number of variables including CCPM classification, referral evaluation and recommendation, and available capacity. The AFP has a number of publicly available stated performance measures against which it monitors its outputs. The AFP makes decisions on the allocation of capacity to crime types and geographical offices based on its understanding of the criminal activity and the requirements of client agencies. As part of its regular performance review, the AFP monitors the potential displacement of current activities by the demands of emerging threats. In particular, the AFP has been vigilant to the possible impact of its overseas operations on its ability to conduct domestic criminal investigations. The AFP monitors its activity through operational hours allocated to a matter and through the results achieved. Performance reports are provided to the National Managers Group each month and to the Executive Management Board every two months, and these provide an opportunity for a number of interventions to occur where decisions concerning resource allocations are seen to impact work delivery. The nature of the AFP’s core activities has changed over the past five years especially with respect to overseas operations. The impact of these changes on domestic operations has been minimal both in terms of activity levels and results achieved. Details of the impact on domestic operations is included in the following answers addressing your specific questions. (1) The IDG deployment force is made up of resources from the AFP’s Outcome1 areas, ACT Policing and from State Police forces. In order to permit the deployment of resources without impact on domestic operations the AFP has specifically a) recruited staff into ACT Policing and specifically into the IDG, b) encouraged voluntary movement of staff across the AFP business streams, c) has redirected some work to offices with available capacity and d) seconded staff to international work directly from state police services. (2) AFP staff do not move to the IDG permanently, but for an agreed period of deployment. This arrangement allows for a fixed term allocation, which in turn is covered through a backfilling strategy. For example a 70-week EOI process allows staff to voluntarily apply to fixed length transfer to encourage movement across AFP business streams to maintain appropriate resource levels. This movement is balanced by recruitment strategies which to date have seen more than 170 staff come into the AFP. The recruitment strategies target a balance between fixed term engagement and permanent appointment to the AFP. (3) The AFP examines the operational case load of each deployed officer well in advance of deployment, and makes decisions about case load and allocation. Prior to deploying a member overseas
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer toor to another geographic location the member and their supervisor review cases allocated to the member to identify cases that can be completed prior to deployment and those needing reallocating to a new case manager. Because of the resource management decisions taken, and because the management of case load is continually reviewed, the AFP has experienced minimal impact on its domestic operations because of its IDG involvement. Performance measures quoted in the following answers, particularly to Question 6, demonstrate this position. (4) Prior to deploying a member overseas or to another geographic location, the member and their supervisor review cases allocated to the member to identify cases that can be completed prior to deployment and those needing re-allocated to a new case officer. When a case is re-allocated the new case officer is provided with briefing and reviews case situation reports to become appraised of the case. In the case of major investigations a second case officer and/or core team may be allocated to the investigation to ensure continuity of investigation. (5) The number of matters rejected is indicative both of internal resource availability and demands by client agencies. Matters rejected increased from a low of 184 in 2000 to a peak of 389 in 2002 (impacted by the Bali bombing investigation), but have since declined to 288 in 2004. (6) The AFP has committed itself to investigating serious crime. Over the five years from 2000 to 2004, the number of High or Very High Impact matters has increased from 386 new cases in 2000 to 700 new cases in 2004. Over the same period, the total number of domestic cases has decreased by 19%, primarily because minor matters have increasingly been handled by alternative strategies, e.g. outposted officers. The number of cases finalised has remained steady over the period. The number of cases resulting in convictions has increased from 282 in 2000 to 300 in 2004. The quantity of illegal drugs seized has remained high over the five-year period increasing from 2.0 tonne in 2000 to 2.6 tonne in 2004. Results in the intervening years are variable. Over the past five years, the AFP has met its Portfolio Budget Target of 65% of resources devoted to High or Very High Impact matters. (7) As indicated above, the AFP will continue to monitor the impact of emerging operational activity on traditional law enforcement activity. Criminal Investigations (Question No. 682) writing, on 7 March 2005: (1) To what extent is information acquired in criminal investigations shared between the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and state law enforcement agencies. (2) Is there a common computer network available to both Commonwealth and State law enforcement agencies for use in investigations as opposed to the information contained in Crimtrac. (3) In circumstances where an AFP officer is investigating a matter, are there procedures or computer systems that automatically advise a state police officer investigating a related matter of additional information that may be added to the AFP investigation files. (4) Are there procedures or computer systems that automatically advise AFP officers of additional information which may be added to State databases. (5) In circumstances where an AFP officer is investigating a matter, are there procedures or computer systems that automatically advise ASIO of any additional information that may be added to the Federal investigation files.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister Representing The Minister For Justice And Customs, In
theText: (6) Are there such procedures or computer systems that automatically advise AFP officers of additional information which may be added to ASIO databases. the honourable member’s question: (1) Information acquired during criminal investigations is shared between the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and State law enforcement agencies to the extent necessary to achieve effective and efficient operational outcomes under the relevant legislative and governance frameworks. (2) No. Joint investigations between the AFP and State law enforcement agencies utilise liaison officers who have access to agency on line services. Joint initiatives between the Commonwealth and State law enforcement agencies are further supplemented by installing AFP and relevant State agencies on line services within the joint investigative team to service the requirements of the investigation. Information is readily shared between the Commonwealth and State law enforcement agencies through the application of a variety of non AFP information systems when appropriate. (3) There are no computer systems which automatically advise either the AFP or State law enforcement agencies of information regarding an investigation. However procedures have been implemented to facilitate information flow between agencies. In any investigation regular consultation occurs between agencies and in many instances agencies are co-located to facilitate information flow. The appointment of agency liaison officers to investigations assists in cross-agency information sharing. The AFP and State police conduct nation wide criminal history checks to access cross-jurisdictional information regarding persons of interest. AFP computer terminals are being progressively installed in State Police Operation Centres (POC) to enable access to AFP systems for specific incidents or investigations. (4) Refer to response (3) above. (5) No. Security protocols do not allow shared computer systems between the AFP and ASIO. There are procedures which facilitate information exchange between ASIO and the AFP. The AFP and ASIO have established a close working relationship, and share information through formal written request and verbally through regular case officer and senior management meetings. (6) Refer to response (5) above. Mr Willie Brigitte (Question No. 691) Since Mr Willie Brigitte was deported from Australia, has ASIO had access to Mr Brigitte for the purpose of conducting an interview; if not, has ASIO or any other government agency sought access. I have responded to questions dealing with Attorney-General’s Department and Australian Federal Police access to Mr Brigitte (Question Numbers 84 and 283 asked on 2 December 2004 in Senate Estimates – copies of those replies are attached). Given the fact that Mr Brigitte is the subject of a current judicial investigation in France and there are legal processes underway in Australia, it would not be appropriate for ASIO to comment further on this matter. theText: General, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Senator Ludwig asked the following question on 2 December 2004: Willie Brigitte (a) Has the Attorney-General’s Department sought any contact with Mr Brigitte following his expulsion from Australia? (b) If so, has the Attorney-General’s Department actually made any such contact? (c) If so, what was the nature of that contact? (d) If so, has Attorney-General’s Department sought any legal advice in relation to this issue? The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows: (a) to (d) No. Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee Australian Federal Police Question No. 283 Senator Ludwig asked the following question on 2 December 2004: (a) Has the AFP sought any contact with Mr Brigitte following his expulsion from Australia? (b) If so, has the AFP actually made any such contact? (c) If so, what was the nature of that contact? (d) If so, has the AFP sought any legal advice in relation to this issue? The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows: (a) Yes. On7 April 2004, members of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) attended the Paris offices of French Judge Bruguiere and attempted to interview Mr Willy Virgile Brigitte. (b) No. Mr Brigitte declined to speak to AFP officers. (c) See the answer to question (b). (d) The AFP regularly liaises with the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney-General’s Department on this matter. Attention Deficit Hyperactive Disorder (Question No. 704) Mr Price asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 7 March 2005: (1) Is he aware of a report prepared by the Parliamentary Library ‘Medication for Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD): an analysis by Federal Electorate (2001 – 03)’. (2) Can he explain the variation in prescriptions for dexamphetamine sulfate between electoral divisions; if not, why not. (3) Does he plan to investigate the diagnosis and treatment of ADHD; if so, how will this be conducted and when; if not, why not. (1) I am aware of the report prepared by the Parliamentary Library ‘Medication for Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD): analysis by Federal Electorate (2001–03). (2) From the data provided in the Electorate reports it is not possible to provide a simple explanation for the variation between electoral divisions in the prescribing of dexamphetamine. Establishing the reasons for such variations is complicated by the uncertainty of the data. Dexamphetamine is currently the only drug listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) specifically for the treatment of ADHD. As dexamphetamine is priced under the general patient co-payment of $28.60,
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:there is limited available information on the number of prescriptions and prescribing patterns. The Health Insurance Commission only collects data where a Government benefit is paid. As such we do not have data on prescriptions that cost less than the general co-payment amount. In addition, as dexamphetamine is classified as a Schedule8 medicine (see 3 below), the states and territories are responsible for collecting data on the prescribing of these drugs. (3) I encourage best practice in providing guidance to doctors on the quality use of medicines. Best practice guidance comes through sources such as the National Health and Medical Research Council and through National Health Priorities initiatives. The Australian Government does not regulate the treatment and prescribing practices of doctors. The decision to prescribe medications, including medicines for the treatment of ADHD, is a judgment made by a doctor approved to prescribe by their respective state and territory health departments with regard to individual circumstances. The states and territories regulate the prescribing of some drugs as they are classified as Schedule8 Drugs– drugs of addiction. Most states and territories only allow dexamphetamine to be prescribed by an ‘authorised’ prescriber, such as a consultant pediatrician or a consultant psychiatrist. Medicines for ADHD should always be prescribed as part of a comprehensive treatment program which includes psychological, educational and social remedial measures. Detoxification Programs (Question No. 706) Ms Hoare asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 8 March 2005: (1) Can he confirm that pharmaceutical products and other treatments are available for patients withdrawing from (a) illicit drug, (b) alcohol, and (c) cigarette use through programs and schemes provided through his department. (2) Can he provide the (a) details and (b) costs of each program and scheme that provides pharmaceutical products and other treatments available for patients withdrawing from (i) illicit drug, (ii) alcohol, and (iii) cigarette use. (3) For each year since 2000, (a) what was the estimated cost borne by the taxpayer, and (b) how many deaths were attributed to (i) illicit drug, (ii) alcohol, and (iii) cigarette use. (1) (a) (b) and (c) The Australian Government has programs that increase the availability of pharmaceutical products for treating dependence on heroin, alcohol, and tobacco. However, the provision of drug and alcohol detoxification (withdrawal) programs is primarily the responsibility of State and Territory Governments. (2) (a) and (b) (i) (ii) and (iii) There is a general Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme subsidy for two drugs used in treating alcohol dependence (acamprosate calcium and naltrexone hydrochloride), and one drug used in treating nicotine dependence (buproprion hydrochloride). In 2003-04, the cost of acamprosate was $3,473,441, naltrexone was $2,078,329, and buproprion was $14,390,389. Under section 100 of the National Health Act 1953, the Australian Government also funds the cost of (a) bulk purchases of methadone hydrochloride syrup supplied to pharmacies, clinics, and hospitals for the management of opiate dependence; and (b) the supply of buprenorphine hydrochloride tablets as recommended for the treatment of opiate dependence, including maintenance and detoxification (withdrawal) within a framework of medical, social and psychological treatment. The funding is by way of reimbursement to the wholesale
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:supplier or importer of the drug. In 2003-04, the cost of methadone to the Australian Government was $4,336,285 and of buprenorphine $15,982,495. Other treatments are the responsibility of state and territory governments. (3) (a) The most recent data on the costs of drug use are for 1998-99. The study, Counting the cost: estimates of the social costs of drug abuse in Australia in 1998-9 was published in 2002. There is no estimate of how much of the total social cost was borne by taxpayers. However, the table at Attachment A shows the estimated tangible costs (such as lost productivity and hospital costs) for illicit drugs, alcohol and tobacco, and the estimated proportion of those costs borne by the government sector, including state and territory governments. The remaining costs were borne by industry and by individuals. (b) (i) (ii) and (iii) Mortality data is predominantly provided by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) and is based on registered death certificates received from state and territory registrars of births, deaths and marriages. Deaths are classified according to ICD-10-AM which is the international statistical classification of diseases and health related problems. ICD-10-AM classifications of deaths from causes including drug use are attributed to the event leading to the death rather than by the specific drug per se. For example, death may be recorded as caused by lung cancer (malignant neoplasm) or a motor vehicle accident. Hence, information on drug-related deaths is not available for every year since 2000. For alcohol and tobacco, the Department has estimates of deaths derived using the aetiological fraction methodology. This methodology relies on the prevalence of a risk factor and associated relative risk of a particular illness or injury. According to the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, the aetiological fractions methodology shows that in 1998 some 19,019 people died in Australia as a result of tobacco smoking. Information from the National Drug Research Institute for alcohol shows that in 2001 an estimated 3,004 people died as a consequence of risky or high risk levels of alcohol consumption. The Australian Bureau of Statistics Information Paper (2003) Drug Induced Deaths 2001 provides some information about deaths attributed to drug use (excluding alcohol, tobacco and volatile substances) in Australia. This indicated that in 2001 there were 1,038 drug-induced deaths registered. Canberra: Department of Health and Ageing Visas (Question No. 708) Dr Lawrence asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 8 March 2005: (1) How many s417 applications are currently before the Minister. (2) How many s417 applications have been delegated to the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to determine. (3) On what basis are s417 applications divided between the Minister and the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs. (4) What is the average processing time for s417 applications from receipt to decision. (5) What proportion of s417 applications are from people currently in immigration detention. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) As at 28 February 2005, there were 1824 s417 requests before both the Minister and the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs. It should be noted that there is no application for Ministerial Intervention under s417. Section 417 of the Migration Act 1958 provides the Minister with the power to substitute for a decision of the Refugee Review Tribunal, a decision which is more favourable to the applicant, if the Minister considers that it is in the public interest to do so. This power is not compellable and the Minister does not have an obligation to consider substituting a more favourable decision in a case. In all cases where a review authority affirms a decision on a Protection Visa application, an assessment against the Minister’s guidelines is undertaken by the Department. If the case falls within the guidelines, a submission is prepared to enable the Minister to decide whether he or she wishes to consider the case for intervention. (2) The s417 power is not delegated. Both Ministers exercise their s417 Ministerial Intervention power in their own right. The division of cases between the two Ministers is broadly determined by whether or not the cases are deemed to be made by individuals in the community or cases deemed to be made by individuals in detention. The division of responsibilities for s417 Ministerial Intervention cases between portfolio Ministers is determined by categories and not by the number of cases. (3) Under administrative arrangements put in place after Minister McGauran was appointed as Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs on 26 October 2004, Senator Vanstone handles section cases covering people who are not in detention. (4) Departmental systems do not maintain statistics on average processing times for Ministerial Intervention processes in a reportable format. Variations in processing may be determined by the individual aspects of a particular case. The power for the Minister to intervene is exhausted only when finalisation of the case is determined. Every person whose case is brought to the Minister’s attention is advised of his or her decision, whether it is a decision to refuse to consider exercising the public interest powers, or a decision following consideration of the exercise of those powers. (5) As at 28 February 2005, there were 1824 requests processed by the Department or being considered by the Minister. Of these, nine per cent or 171 requests were detention cases. Child-Care Centres (Question No. 711) Ms George asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 8 March 2005: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 82 (Hansard, 8 February 2005, pages 82-87), for each financial year from 2000-01 to 2003-04, what sum was provided to each (a) private and (b) community based child care centre in the electoral division of Throsby within the Child Care Rebate range (i) 1 to 25 per cent CCB, (ii) 26 to 50 per cent CCB, (iii) 51 to 75 per cent CCB, and (iv) 76 to 100 per cent CCB. (2) Can the Minister confirm that 70 per cent of child care places for children 0-2 years of age in the electoral division of Throsby are being delivered through the community-based sector.

speaker: Mr Hockey
theText: The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the followelectoral division of Throsby due to flexible licensing arrangements and individual service operating practices. (3) The Long Day Care Incentive Scheme provides not-for-profit and for-profit providers with short term incentives to encourage the establishment of new viable long day care centres in rural and urban fringe areas of high unmet demand. The funding for Long Day Care Incentive Scheme encourages additional places for children under 24 months through the provision of higher per place funding to this age group. Places for children under 2 years receive $30 per place, per week incentive funding and places for over 2 years receive $15 per place, per week incentive funding. Sustainability Assistance is available to existing eligible not-for-profit Long Day Care services. It is targeted to areas of need approved by the department as a contribution to support viability. Sustainability Assistance gives a higher weighting to services that have places for children under 24 months. (4) There are no requirements for private providers in areas of high demand to provide places for children under 2 years of age. However, through the Long Day Care Incentive Scheme, services in rural and urban fringe areas of high unmet demand are encouraged to have places for this age group through the provision of higher per place funding for children under 24 months. Government and Non-Government Schools (Question No. 713) Ms Livermore asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 8 March 2005: (1) What sum was provided in 2004 to (a) government, and (b) non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and in the postcode area (i) 4699, (ii) 4700, (iii) 4701, (iv) 4702, (v) 4703, (vi) 4704, (vii) 4705, (viii) 4706, (ix) 4707, (x) 4710, (xi) 4712, (xii) 4713, (xiii) 4714, (xiv) 4715, (xv) 4716, (xvi) 4717, (xvii) 4718, (xviii) 4719, (xix) 4721, (xx) 4741, (xxi) 4742, (xxii) 4743, (xxiii) 4744, (xxiv) 4745, (xxv) 4746, and (xxvi) 4804. (2) What was the (a) expenditure on, (b) location of, and (c) purpose of each grant in 2004. (3) What sum will be provided in 2005 to (a) government, and (b) non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and the postcode area (i) 4699, (ii) 4700, (iii) 4701, (iv) 4702, (v) 4703, (vi) 4704, (vii) 4705, (viii) 4706, (ix) 4707, (x) 4710, (xi) 4712, (xii) 4713, (xiii) 4714, (xiv) 4715, (xv) 4716, (xvi) 4717, (xvii) 4718, (xviii) 4719, (xix) 4721, (xx) 4741, (xxi) 4742, (xxii) 4743, (xxiii) 4744, (xxiv) 4745, (xxv) 4746, and (xxvi) 4804. (4) What will (a) the expenditure be for, (b) be the location of, and (c) be the purpose of each grant in 2005. (1) (a) Total Australian Government funding for government schools is not reported at the level of detail requested. Australian Government General Recurrent Grants for government schools are provided to the government education authority in each State or Territory, on the basis to total enrolments. The State or Territory determines where the grants are used. Payments to individual schools are not recorded. The Department of Education, Science and Training only provides postcode detail for General Recurrent Grants and Establishment Grants to non-government schools, and Capital Grants, Flagpole funding and funding for the Boys’ Education Lighthouse Schools (BELS) project to both government and non-government schools. In 2004, Flagpole funding amounting to $2,753 was provided to government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identi-
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Dr Nelson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:fied postcodes. No Capital or BELS funding was provided to government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes in 2004. (b) Total Australian Government funding for non-government schools cannot be reported at the level of detail requested. Funding from Australian Government programmes that can be reported at this level of detail for non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified post codes totalled $33,028,552.60. Of this amount, Capital Grants funding provided $269,995, Flagpole funding provided $1,500 and General Recurrent Grants funding provided $32,757,057.60 to non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes for 2004. No Establishment Grant funding or BELS funding was provided to non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes in 2004. (2) (a) (b) Details on the expenditure and location for the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes for 2004 are as follows: Flagpole Funding to government schools is at Table 1, Attachment A; Capital Grants to non-government schools is at Table 2, Attachment A; Flagpole Funding to non-government schools is at Table 3, Attachment A; and General Recurrent funding to non-government schools is at Table4 at Attachment A. (c) The purpose of the Australian Government Capital Grants is to assist in the provision of school facilities, particularly in ways that contribute most to raising the overall level of educational achievement of Australian school students. The purpose of Flagpole funding is to assist schools with their civics and citizenship education activities, and promoting values education in Australian schools. The purpose of Australian Government General Recurrent Grants is to help schools with the recurrent cost of school education so that they can offer students education directed towards the achievement of the Australian Government’s priorities for schooling. (3) (a) Estimates of total Australian Government funding for 2005 for government schools are not maintained at the level of detail requested (see response to 1a). Information about 2005 Capital Grants for government schools is not yet available. To date, no Flagpole funding or BELS funding has been provided to government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes in 2005. (b) Estimates of total Australian Government funding for 2005 for non-government schools are not maintained at the level of detail requested. Estimated funding from Australian Government Programmes that can be reported at this level of detail for non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes amounted to $37,278,600 for 2005. Of this amount, Capital Grants funding will provide an estimated $902,667 and General Recurrent Grants funding will provide an estimated $36,375,933 for non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes for 2005. To date, no Flagpole funding, Establishment or BELS funding has been provided to non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes for 2005. (4) (a) and (b) Details on the estimated expenditure and location for the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes for 2005 are as follows: Estimated Capital grants to nongovernment schools is at Table5 at Attachment A; Estimated General Recurrent Grants to non-government schools is at Table6 at Attachment A. (c) The purpose of the Australian Government Capital Grants is to assist in the provision of school facilities, particularly in ways that contribute most to raising the overall level of educational achievement of Australian school students. The purpose of Australian Government General Recurrent Grants is to help schools with the recurrent cost of school education so that they can offer students education directed towards the achievement of the Australian Government’s priorities for schooling. Child-Care Centres (Question No. 715) Ms Livermore asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 8 March 2005: (1) How many (a) community-based and (b) private childcare centres are located in the electoral division of Capricornia and what is the name and address of each centre. (2) In respect of each centre, what sum did the Commonwealth provide for the financial year (a) 200001, (b) 2001-02, (c) 2002-03, and (d) 2003-04 and from which programs was the funding provided. (3) How many children in the electoral division of Capricornia were catered for in (a) communitybased, and (b) private childcare centres. (4) How many children in the electoral division of Capricornia are (a) under 2 years of age, and (b) under 2 years of age and enrolled in (i) community based and (ii) private child care centres. (5) How many Commonwealth funded places for (a) Before School Care, (b) After School Care, and (c) Vacation Care are there in the electoral division of Capricornia. (6) Which organisations in the electorate of Capricornia coordinate the provision of these services. ing answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (a) (b) In September 2004, there were 67 Australian Government funded child care services in the electoral division of Capricornia. Of these, 47 were community services and 20 were private services. (5) (a) (b) (c) Since 2001, Centrelink has been combining co-located and co-managed After School and Before School Hours Care services as a single administered Outside School Hours Care service. As at September 2004, the number of approved places for Outside School Hours Care in the electorate of Capricornia was 555 and the number of approved places for Vacation Care was 575. (6) In September 2004, organisations which operated Outside School Hours Care child care services within the electorate of Capricornia were as follows: Operator Anglicare Central Queensland Capcare Association Inc Central Queensland University Dysart Vacation Care Programme Emu Park Parents& Citizens Association Middlemount Kindacare Operator Moranbah Neighbourhood Centre Association Inc Queensland Police-Citizens’ Youth Welfare Association Roman Catholic Trust Corporation For The Diocese Of Rockhampton The Caves State School Parents And Citizens Association Young Women’s Christian Association -Rockhampton Source: Centrelink administrative data 27-09-04. Job Network Providers (Question No. 721) Ms Livermore asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 8 March 2005: (1) How many Job Network providers are currently operating in the electoral division of Capricornia and what are their names and addresses. (2) How many job seekers are currently registered with (a) each Job Network provider, and (b) each office of each provider operating in the electoral division of Capricornia. (3) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, in (i) Australia, and (ii) the electoral division of Capricornia, how many Newstart or Youth Allowance recipients were placed into jobs through assistance from Job Network providers. (4) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many long-term unemployed people (i) in total, and (ii) as a proportion of all unemployed people, participated in intensive assistance programs in the electoral division of Capricornia. (5) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many of the people who participated in intensive assistance in the electoral division of Capricornia have participated on (i) one occasion, (ii) two occasions, (iii) three occasions, and (iv) more than three occasions. (6) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many job seekers who participated in intensive assistance in the electoral division of Capricornia found employment and what proportion found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time, and (iii) casual employment. (7) How many Work for the Dole providers are currently operating in the electoral division of Capricornia, what are their names and addresses and what programs do they offer. (8) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Capricornia found employment. (9) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, what proportion of people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Capricornia found (i) full time, (ii) part-time, and (iii) casual employment following their placement. (10) For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Capricornia were in (i) full-time, (ii) part-time, and (iii) casual employment three months after completing their placement. (1) and (2) Job Network is administered on the basis of 19 Labour Market Regions and 137 Employment Services Areas (ESAs), the boundaries of which do not align with those of Federal Electorates. Job seekers choose Job Network members for a variety of reasons including location, proximity to transport routes and Centrelink offices, or the satisfaction of friends and others. Job seekers residing in one Electorate or ESA may be assisted through Job Network sites located in adjoining Electorates or ESAs. For illustration, job seekers residing in the Electorate of Capricornia may be assisted through Job Network sites located in the Electorates of Dawson, Kennedy, Maranoa or
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Hinkler. The Emerald ESA, Gladstone ESA, Mackay ESA, Rockhampton ESA and Townsville ESA are most closely aligned with the Electorate of Capricornia and, therefore, answers are provided with reference to these five ESAs. There are currently 12 Job Network members and other Job Placement Organisations operating in the Emerald ESA, 11 in the Gladstone ESA, 20 in the Mackay ESA, 18 in the Rockhampton ESA and 40 in the Townsville ESA. Their names, office locations and the number of job seekers on their caseloads are shown in Table 1. (5) In view of the 12 month duration of Intensive Assistance it is not practical to report on the numbers of job seekers who participated on multiple occasions in 2000, 2001, 2002 and 2003. Delivery of Intensive Assistance ceased on 30 June 2003. From1 July 2003, improvements to the delivery of Job Network services were introduced through implementation of the APM. While Intensive Assistance allowed for multiple episodes of assistance, the new APM arrangements provide for job seekers to be assisted by a single Job Network member for the full duration of their unemployment, allowing the service provider to develop a detailed understanding of each job seeker’s needs. (6) The Post-Programme Monitoring (PPM) survey conducted by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations measures job seekers’ outcomes three months after they have left assistance. PPM survey results are an estimate of outcomes levels based on responses from a sample of clients. Socio-Economic Status Funding (Question No. 727) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 8 March 2005: (1) Can he confirm that the Socio-Economic Status (SES) funding formula is an aggregate statistic measuring the economic status of districts and not individual families or individual schools; if not, why not. (2) Can he confirm that the SES funding formula gives a potentially misleading indicator of educational need and results in the overly generous funding of some independent non-government schools with boarding facilities; if not, why not. (3) Will the Government review the formula used to allocate Commonwealth funding to independent schools; if so, when; if not, why not. (1) The SES methodology calculates an SES score for each school based on all the Census Collection Districts (CDs) from which the school draws it students. The data present an average socioeconomic profile of the school community, that is, the families of students at the school. The SES model does not set out to measure the wealth of any individual family or school, but rather to rank schools relative to each other based on the SES of each school’s community. Following the SES Simulation Project undertaken in 1998, a series of validation exercises were carried out using the simulation results against other parental income and wealth measures. The findings of the validation exercises support the view that a Census-based SES measure produces a good proxy for parental socioeconomic status, without the intrusiveness and administrative complexity inherent in measuring parental income more directly. (2) The SES approach is a transparent and objective measure based on Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Census data that are consistent for all schools. The SES Index that is used to calculate schools’ SES scores measures the income, education and occupation levels of all residents within a CD. The SES score of each student’s home CD is the only factor that contributes to the school’s SES score. There is no discrimination between boarding and non-boarding students. Data collected by the Department of Education, Science and Training in 2003 show that there were over 140 independent boarding schools, enrolling some 11,000 boarding students. These students come from a wide range of CDs in both urban and rural areas, with about 45 per cent coming from urban areas. The data also show that schools with boarding students are not advantaged by the SES funding formula. In many instances, boarding schools which are located in the same area as day schools have a similar or higher SES score than the day schools. For example: there are two boarding schools located in Wahroonga, NSW; the four other non-government schools located in this suburb all have lower SES scores in Hawthorn, Victoria there are six non-government schools, one of which is an boarding school with an SES score of 124; three of the remaining schools have scores below 124 while the other two have scores of 125 there are five schools located in Brisbane, one of which is a boarding school with an SES score of 116; the other four schools have scores of 102, 113, 117 and 119 the two boarding schools in the ACT have SES scores of 119 and 124; the 13 other schools in the ACT, which also cater for secondary students, have scores ranging from 100 to 122.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Dr Nelson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(3) A review of the SES funding arrangements will be undertaken during the current quadrennium. The review will involve consultations with all non-government school groups and these discussions will inform policy development for the funding of non-government schools for 2009-2012. Fruit and Vegetable Growers (Question No. 735) Mrs Elliot asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 9 March 2005: (1) What is the Government doing to relieve pressure on fruit and vegetable growers who are experiencing falling income due to increased costs? (2) What assistance is available to farmers who are currently experiencing loss of income? (3) What is the Government doing to assist fruit and vegetable growers meet increased costs? (1) While it would be inappropriate to directly intervene in private sector markets, the Government has introduced a range of measures to improve the competitiveness of fruit and vegetable growers. The Government has gained improved access to export markets for fruit and vegetable growers and recently introduced legislation to amend the Trade Practices Act to make it quicker, simpler and easier to collectively negotiate with buyers of their produce. The Government also provides matching research and development funding for fruit and vegetable industries, to help them lower industry costs and provides support for industry training. (2) There are a number of Government programs available to assist farmers experiencing a loss of income. The Agriculture – Advancing Australia Farm Help Program, is the Government’s key means of providing short term income support to low-income farm families who are experiencing financial hardship. There is also Exceptional Circumstances Assistance for farmers experiencing a severe and prolonged decline in income due to a rare and severe event. Interim income support is also available where a prima facie case for Exceptional Circumstances Assistance has been demonstrated. (3) The Government helps farmers including fruit and vegetable growers face challenges such as increased costs through its Agriculture – Advancing Australia package of programs. This package of programs is targeted at helping producers become more competitive, sustainable and profitable by improving business management, supporting families through change, providing access to professional advice, improving access to markets and building industry capacity to meet future challenges. Australian Government funding of over $1 billion since 1997 for these programs demonstrates the Government’s strong commitment to ensuring the long-term prosperity of rural and regional Australia. Joint Strike Fighter (Question No. 737) Mr Bevis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 9 March 2005: (1) Is the Minister aware of reports that the Joint Strike Fighter’s (JSF) development costs have risen to about $38 billion. (2) Is the Minister aware that part of the reported increase is being attributed to the United States Department of Defense’s demand for anti-tampering safeguards to prevent sensitive technologies being passed on to enemies.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Truss
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(3) If Australia decides to purchase the JSF, will Australia have access to technology in key areas including the weapons’ guidance and navigation systems in the JSF. Mrs De-Anne Kelly-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Yes, additional design effort and extension of the System Development and Demonstration phase of the Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) Program has led to an increase in the cost estimate from US$33 billion to US$40.5 billion. (2) The Minister is aware of the United States requirement for anti-tamper software to protect sensitive JSF technologies. However, the specific element of the breakdown of costs for the increase is not yet known. (3) Defence staff have been provided with detailed classified briefings on the high level of JSF capability that will be offered to Australia to allow us to operate and support the JSF. Generator Refurbishment (Question No. 738) Mr Bevis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 9 March 2005: (1) Did the Army invite tenders in July 2002 for the refurbishment of generators obtained from the United Kingdom Ministry of Defence; if so, (a) who was the successful tenderer, (b) when was the successful tenderer announced, and (c) has a contract been signed with the successful tenderer; if so when; if not, why not. (2) When did the debriefing of the unsuccessful tenderers take place. (3) What will be the total cost of obtaining and refurbishing these generators. (4) Would it have been more cost effective to replace the old generators with new, modern, low emission generators; if not, can the Minister explain why not; if so, why was that course of action not adopted. Mrs De-Anne Kelly-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The Defence Materiel Organisation obtained 59 generators from the UK Ministry of Defence. BAE Systems refurbished 39 generators within the scope of the Rapier Life of Type Extension Project (LAND 140). A sole-source contract was raised with BAE Systems for the refurbishment of the remaining 20 generators. Subsequently, a tender was raised for the modification of these 20 generators. (a) Advanced Power. (b) 4 February 2003. (c) Yes, on 31 January 2003. (2) The debriefing of the unsuccessful tenderer occurred by telephone in early 2003 and was followed up by a letter dated 21 March 2003. (3) $440,346.14. (4) No. Investigations established that commercially available new generators would need to be modified to meet the power requirements; the cost of the new generators, plus modifications, was substantially greater than the cost of the refurbished generators. Furthermore, there were advantages of commonality with existing generators in refurbishing and modifying the United Kingdomsourced generators. Generator Refurbishment (Question No. 739) Mr Bevis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 9 March 2005: (1) Did the Army stage an industry briefing for the refurbishment of a large number of 60 and 120 KVA generators in June 2001. (2) When were the tender documents for this refurbishment made available. (3) Who was the successful tenderer. (4) When was the contract with the successful tenderer signed. (5) When did the debriefing of the unsuccessful tenderers take place. (6) Was an alternative tenderer named as a back-up; if so, who was it; if not, why not. (7) What was the amount of the original, successful tender. (8) What sums have been paid so far to the successful tenderer for the refurbishment work. (9) What is the final total sum expected to be paid. (10) Will all the conditions of the tender document be strictly followed; if not, which conditions are not being enforced. Mrs De-Anne Kelly-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) No, the Defence Materiel Organisation conducted the industry briefing. (2) 22 January 2003. (3) Cummins Engine Company Pty Ltd. (4) 12 December 2003. (5) Between 31 July 2003 and 2 September 2003. (6) No, all other tenders exceeded the allocated budget. (7) $3,784,348.98 (GST exclusive). (8) $49,411.00 (GST exclusive) as at 9 March 2005. (9) $4,262,240.93 (GST exclusive). (10) Yes. The draft contract, included in the request for tender, has been amended through contract negotiations, and subsequent contract change proposals as allowed for in the request for tender. Jet Engine Air-Start Units (Question No. 740) Mr Bevis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 9 March 2005: (1) When were the tender documents made available for replacement Jet Engine Air-Start Units for the RAAF. (2) Did the RAAF have any trial units from the manufacturers either before or during the tender process; if so, what were the names of the firms that (a) manufactured and (b) supplied the trial units. (3) How long were tenderers advised that the evaluation of the tenders would take. (4) How long did the evaluation of the tenders actually take. (5) How many tenderers were there. (6) Was a shortlist of tenderers produced; if so, how many firms were on the short list. (7) When was the contract signed with the successful tenderer. (8) When did the debriefing of the unsuccessful tenderers take place. (9) Was an alternative tenderer named as back-up; if so, who was it; if not, why not. (10) Which firm won the tender. Mrs De-Anne Kelly-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The tender documents for replacement Air Start Units were made available on the following dates: Request For Tender released 14 January 2004; Industry Brief 15 February 2004; and Closing date – 12.00 pm on 15 March 2004. (2) Not directly. The Strike Reconnaissance Systems Program Office (SRSPO) trialed a Rheinmetall Landsysteme GmbH unit, supplied by MONZ Australia, at RAAF Amberley on an F-111 Engine Test Cell (August/September 2002), while investigating whether to replace the fleet of Air Start Units supporting the F-111 aircraft. However, the SRSPO did not continue with any acquisition of the units and was not involved in the acquisition or the tender evaluation for the 25 units procured by the Aerospace Equipment Systems Support Office to support other Australian Defence Force aircraft. (3) Four weeks, commencing on 15 March 2004 and concluding on 5 April 2004. (4) Twenty weeks, and was completed by the Tender Evaluation Team on 22 August 2004. (5) Fifteen. (6) Yes, ten. (7) 15 November 2004. (8) Tenderer debriefing took place on or shortly after 25 November 2004 for those tenderers who requested a debrief. (9) No, because all other tenders were considered non-compliant to some degree and, therefore, not considered suitable alternatives. (10) MONZ Australia. Detention Centres (Question No. 750) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005: How many (a) psychiatrists, (b) doctors, and (c) interpreters speaking (i) Farsi/Dari, (ii) Pashtun, (iii) Uzbek and (iv) Tajik have been employed or contracted by the department or its contractors in Australian detention centres or alternative holding centres. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (a) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) utilises a number of psychiatrists, psychologists and counsellors in its immigration detention facilities, in the following manner:
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous AffairsAt Baxter Immigration Detention Facility (IDF), a psychiatrist visits approximately every 6 weeks, depending on case requirements. One psychologist and one counsellor are also available during business hours, Monday to Friday. At Villawood Immigration Detention Centre (IDC), an onsite General Practitioner (GP) refers clients to a private off-site psychiatrist. For acute and/or urgent treatment, a Mental Health Unit can be accessed via Bankstown Emergency department (Banks House). In addition, there is one full-time psychologist and three part-time psychologists on-site. At Maribyrnong IDC, there is a visiting psychiatrist who attends every 4 to 6 weeks. For acute and/or urgent treatment, either Werribee Mercy Hospital Psychiatric Unit can be accessed via Outpatient appointment or tele-consultation may take place via Crises Assessment and Treatment (CAT) Service. In addition, there is one full-time psychologist and one part-time counsellor on-site and one psychologist on call to see detainees on a needs basis. At Perth IDC, non-emergency, tele-consultations may take place with a psychiatrist, as well as outpatient appointments via Bentley Clinic. Acute or non-acute consultations or non-voluntary admissions may take place via Bentley and Greylands Hospitals. There is also one part-time psychologist on-site. At Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (IRPC), a GP may consult with WA Mental Health Services via the phone. Acute psychiatric patients may be sent to Perth. A visiting psychologist attends one week per month. (b) DIMIA also utilises a number of doctors in its immigration detention facilities, in the following manner: At Baxter IDF, one doctor attends a daily GP clinic on-site, Monday to Friday. There is also one doctor on-call 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. At Villawood IDC, three doctors provide five clinics from Monday to Friday, and one doctor provides a clinic on Saturday. There is one doctor, who can be contacted via nurse, on-call 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. At Maribyrnong IDC, one doctor provides two clinics from Monday to Friday, and one doctor is on-call 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. At Perth IDC, one doctor provides a clinic each Tuesday and one doctor is on-call 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. At Christmas Island IRPC, people in detention have the same access to medical care as Christmas Island residents, i.e. consultations via Christmas Island Hospital. One doctor is on call 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. (c) Both DIMIA and contracted staff, including psychiatrists and doctors, offer and utilise interpreters whenever necessary. The interpreting needs of DIMIA and its contractors are met in the following manner: (i) For Farsi/Dari interpreters, as at 30 March 2005, there are three interpreters employed by the Detention Service Provider, GSL. Two interpreters were previously employed by GSL, completing their employment in May 2004 and February 2005 respectively. (ii) For Pashtun interpreters, telephone interpreting agencies are used. (iii) For Uzbek interpreters, telephone interpreting agencies are used. (iv) For Tajik interpreters, telephone interpreting agencies are used. Refugees (Question No. 760) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005: (1) In respect of those people who could not prove their claims for refugee status, how many were able to show discrimination or threat, not amounting to persecution under the Geneva Convention but enough to make them flee their country, that was not substantial enough for them to gain protection in Australia. (2) How many people had claims of persecution which were not accepted on the basis that the situation had changed since they fled (ie Afghans whose claims were based on persecution by the Taliban). (3) From which countries did the remaining people originate. (4) How long did it take to assess these people’s claims for refugee status. (5) Has the department been developing any further cost effective ways of ensuring that the remaining non-refugees and refugees are identified. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) systems do not record this information in a reportable form. (2) DIMIA systems do not record this information in a reportable form. (3) DIMIA systems do not record this information in a reportable form. (4) DIMIA systems are unable to report on this matter. (5) The Department constantly reviews the process of assessing applications for further protection to ensure they are processed in the most streamlined, cost-effective and rigorous manner. Australia has one of the most efficient and reliable refugee assessment processes in the world. The proportion of those claiming refugee protection who are in need of Australia’s protection varies widely according to their particular claims, their nationality, and the human rights situation in their homeland at the time. The major constraint to further reductions in the cost of decision making are the safeguards in the existing processes to provide individuals with an equitable opportunity to present their case, to receive and comment on any adverse personal information relating to their claims, which might be taken into account by the decision-maker, and to provide applicants with detailed reasons for any refusal decision and opportunities for merits review. Immigration Detention (Question No. 761) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005: How many people held in Australian detention centres awaiting deportation are currently serving parole in relation to offences committed under federal or state laws. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: As at 18 February 2005, there were 973 people in immigration detention. Of these, 45 people were detained as a direct result of criminal activity leading to decisions pursuant to sections 200 and 501 of the Act. Of these people:

Temporary Protection Visas (Question No. 765) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005: (1) How many Iraqi asylum seekers are on (a) expired and (b) soon to expire temporary protection visas. (2) How many in (1) are awaiting the determination of a claim for continuing protection. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (a) and (b) Where a Temporary Protection Visa (TPV) holder applies for further protection before the expiry date of their TPV, the TPV status can continue until the application for further protection is finally determined. This means that the only Iraqi TPV grantees whose TPVs have expired are those who either did not apply for further protection before their TPV expired, or have been finally determined not to be refugees. As at 25 February 2005, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) records indicate that some 20 Iraqi nationals in Australia have had their TPV status expire. (2) As at 25 February 2005 some 2850 applications for further protection, from Iraqi TPV grantees whose TPV has reached 30 months from grant date, are still to be decided by the Department. Temporary Protection Visas (Question No. 766) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005: (1) Does the Minister’s department propose to re-assess every individual applicant who applies for permanent protection when their TPV expires. (2) How many applicants have applied for such protection. (3) How many applicants have been approved at their first review. (4) How many applicants have appealed to the Refugee Review Tribunal. (5) How many applicants have left Australia voluntarily. (6) How many applicants are awaiting decisions. (7) What is the estimated cost of assessing each applicant. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Yes. The Department is under a statutory obligation to assess and decide protection visa applications. (2) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) records indicate that as at 25 February 2005 some 9,300 applications for further protection have been lodged.

theText: The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs
