speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous AffairsWhether any further visa granted is a temporary or permanent visa will depend on a number of factors, including the person’s actions as they travelled to Australia. (3) DIMIA records indicate that as at 25 February 2005, some 2,500 grants have been made at the primary decision stage on applications for further protection. (4) DIMIA records indicate that as at 25 February 2005, some 1,500 decisions on applications for further protection have been appealed to the Refugee Review Tribunal. (5) DIMIA systems show that as at 27 February 2005, some 320 former Temporary Protection Visa (TPV) holders have departed Australia without waiting for resolution of a further protection visa application. Reports on departures of Temporary Humanitarian Visa holders are not currently available. (6) DIMIA records indicate that as at 25 February 2005, some 4,800 applications for further protection were awaiting a departmental decision at primary stage. (7) DIMIA financial systems do not allow processing costs of applications for further protection to be disaggregated from the other protection visa processing costs incurred by the Department. Refugees (Question No. 768) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005: (1) What advice has the Minister’s department given to Afghan refugees about the safety of returning to Afghanistan. (2) What information has the department used to make that assessment and does this include specific information regarding the refugees’ former areas of residence. (3) What information is there on the situation facing refugees of Hazara ethnicity. (4) What criteria are officers using to determine claims for permanent protection. (5) Has the department received assurances that it is safe to return these refugees. (6) What legal advice has been sought on this matter. (7) What legal advice has been sought on the view that only the UNHCR has the right to remove refugee protection. (8) Will the Minister explain the application of the cessation clauses of the Convention in these cases. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Australia does not return anybody who is found to be a refugee to a place of persecution. People who have been found to be refugees are free to leave Australia at any time should they wish to do so and are not obliged to inform the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) of this. DIMIA does not advise clients about safety in returning to their home country. Some 3.5 million Afghan refugees and former refugees have returned to Afghanistan in recent years, many under UNHCR auspices (including some 200,000 Afghans of Hazara ethnicity). (2) As stated above, DIMIA does not provide advice on safety to return. The Department’s Country Information Service maintains information on provinces and districts of concern within Afghanistan from a wide range of sources. (3) The Department’s Country Information Service maintains comprehensive information on the human rights and security situations in countries around the world. Afghanistan, including Afghans of the Hazara ethnicity, is a priority for country research. The Country Information Service is in close consultation with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade network of overseas posts as
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairswell as the equivalent governmental country research agencies in Europe and North America. There is also close consultation with non-government and inter-governmental organisations (dealing with human rights concerns) and individual country experts, as well as extensive and continuous monitoring of academic, media and Internet information sources. (4) A decision-maker must be satisfied that the applicant has met all legislative requirements for grant of a permanent protection visa. One of these requirements is that the decision-maker is satisfied that the applicant is owed protection obligations under the Refugees Convention. In reaching their conclusion the decision-maker considers whether the applicant has a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention reason at the time of decision. (5) Australia does not return anybody who is found to be a refugee. The Australian Government has not sought such assurances. The most effective way to ensure that persons do not suffer persecution if returned to their homeland is to have a robust process to identify refugees and protect them so that they are not returned. Australia has such a process which includes access to merits review by an independent tribunal of any unsuccessful protection claim. Applicants who are unsuccessful at the tribunal level have access to judicial review by the courts. Their cases are closely and regularly monitored to identify any instances in which the Ministerial intervention powers may be appropriately used to either to allow a fresh protection visa application to be lodged or to grant a visa on non refugee grounds. This process allows consideration of claims that may raise Australia’s protection obligations under other international human rights instruments to which Australia is a party. The persons returned have been conclusively found not to face any well founded fear of persecution. To date there have been no involuntary returns to Afghanistan. (6) The Department has not sought legal advice on this matter. (7) The Refugees Convention does not in any way provide that the cessation clauses can only be applied by the UNHCR, or that only UNHCR can remove refugee protection. The interpretation and obligations under the Refugees Convention is a matter for State parties to the Convention. (8) Where an application for a further protection visa has been made, it is necessary for decisionmakers to be satisfied afresh that the applicant has a well-founded fear of persecution for a convention reason. This assessment includes an assessment of whether the cessation clauses of the Convention apply to all of the claims made by the applicant, at the time of decision. To date, the courts have agreed with the Department’s approach to assessment. The Department has been successful in all eight matters involving applicants for further protection which have proceeded to final court hearing and judgment. Temporary Protection Visas (Question No. 769) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005: (1) What is the cost of the reprocessing of Temporary Protection Visa (TPV) claims. (2) Have additional staff been engaged to reprocess TPV claims; if not, would the staff reprocessing TPV claims otherwise have been reallocated to other duties. (3) How many Afghan asylum seekers have returned since the reintegration package for Afghan refugees was announced on 16 December 2002. (4) What follow-up has been done to ensure the safety and well-being of these people. (5) Have departmental officers carried out follow-up visits; if so, when. (6) Has a report been commissioned to consider the re-settlement conditions and well-being of these people. (7) Can the Minister say how many Afghan returnees under the Government’s reintegration package have left Afghanistan for a neighbouring country; if so, (a) to which countries did they go and (b) is the Australian Government aware of the reasons why they are moving. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) DIMIA financial systems do not allow processing costs of applications for further protection to be disaggregated from the other protection visas processing costs incurred by the Department. (2) Staffing resources have been progressively adjusted to match ongoing community caseloads as well as further protection caseloads, drawing on existing Departmental resources and recruitment as necessary. (3) Sixty seven failed Afghan asylum seekers have returned to Afghanistan since 16 December 2002. (4) The Department does not monitor returnees. Australia has effective processes to protect refugees so they are not sent home in the first place. The people in question have had access to that process and were found not to need protection. Australia does not return anybody who is found to be a refugee to a place of persecution. People who have been found to be refugees are free to leave Australia at any time should they wish to do so and are not obliged to inform the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) of this. DIMIA does not advise clients about safety in returning to their home country. Some 3.5 million Afghan refugees and former refugees have returned to Afghanistan in recent years, many under UNHCR auspices (including some 200,000 Afghans of Hazara ethnicity). (5) No. (6) No. (7) No. It is not known how many, if any, Afghan returnees have left Afghanistan for a neighbouring country. (a) This is not known. (b) No. Darwin to Alice Springs Railway (Question No. 779) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, in writing, on 10 March 2005: (1) With respect to the construction of the Darwin to Alice Springs Railway, what was the (a) full cost of construction and (b) current contribution by each investor including the Australian, South Australian and Northern Territory Governments? (2) In considering the initial decision to invest in the railway and subsequent additional contributions, (a) what projections were made in the business case for the carriage of (i) passengers, (ii) domestic freight, and (iii) international freight and (b) what has been achieved by the railway to date for the carriage of (i) passengers, (ii) domestic freight, and (iii) international freight since the opening of the railway? (3) Have any consultations occurred between the operator of the railway and the Commonwealth and the South Australian or Northern Territory Governments concerning potential additional financial contributions relating to the operation of the railway? (1) (a) $1.3 billion. (b) The Australian and Northern Territory Governments are each contributing up to $191.4 million and the South Australian Government is contributing up to $176.4 million. The remaining $740.2 million was funded by the private Asia Pacific Transport Consortium.

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) (a) The Australian Government’s decision to contribute funds to the project was not based on any one particular feasibility study but on the significant benefits that the rail link would provide to the Northern Territory, South Australia and the entire nation. (b) The Great Southern Railway, operator of the passenger service on the Adelaide to Darwin Railway, reported that in its first year of service The Ghan carried over 70,000 passengers. FreightLink, operator of the freight services on the Adelaide to Darwin Railway, reported that nearly 600,000 tonnes of freight were carried in its first 12 months, some 220,000 tonnes above its first year target of 380,000 tonnes. FreightLink, operator of the freight services on the Adelaide to Darwin Railway, reported that more than 16,000 tonnes of freight were exported via the Port of Darwin. (3) The Australian Government has had no consultations with the operator of the railway concerning potential additional financial contributions relating to the operations of the railway. Sir Laurence Street: Appointment (Question No. 784) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 10 March 2005: (1) What was the nature of the selection or tender process used to appoint the former Justice, Mr Street, to advise the Government on priority issues related to the tender process for defence ship construction. (2) What was the nature of the consultation between the Government and Mr Street leading to this engagement. (3) Who initiated the contract and who was involved in consultations relating to his engagement. (4) In respect of Mr Street’s consultancy, (a) what is its duration, (b) from which location will he work, and (c) is there a statement of the duties he is to carry out; if so, (i) what is it, (ii) when was it agreed, and (iii) what is the contracted cost of office accommodation and secretarial support for the duration of the contract. (5) What are the terms of, and conditions of payment for, Mr Street’s consultancy (including superannuation payments, travel entitlements, salary and whether he will be paid in the form of salary or whether fees will be paid to a company structure). Mrs De-Anne Kelly-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The Secretary, Department of Defence, chose Sir Laurence Street based upon his proven competency and expertise in this line of work. The Secretary considered alternatives before making his decision, and judged that Sir Laurence’s experience in this area fitted him best for the task. (2) The only consultation with Sir Laurence Street was conducted by the Secretary, Department of Defence, and Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Defence Materiel Organisation. (3) The contract was initiated by the Secretary, Department of Defence. The Secretary consulted with the Deputy Chief Executive Officer and General Counsel, Defence Materiel Organisation. (4) (a) 400 hours. This may be extended by mutual agreement. (b) Meetings and conferences will be attended principally in both Sydney and Canberra. (c) Yes. (i) To act as an independent adviser to the Department of Defence, Defence Materiel Organisation, for the Air Warfare Destroyer Project, Amphibious Ship Project and sale of ASC activities, providing advice with respect to agency stakeholder governance including process integrity, conflict of interest management and probity review. (ii) 5 January 2005. (iii) Nil. (5) Sir Laurence will be paid per hour plus GST for time spent on the consultancy in attending meetings and conferences, and for time spent on the consultancy in general consideration including reading of documents and research. Time spent on the consultancy shall include time out of the consultant’s office in attending meetings and conferences, but will not include travelling time in attending meetings and conferences in Sydney. Travel expenses will be paid by Defence. Sir Laurence has been engaged as an individual. World Health Organisation Framework (Question No. 785) Mr Melham asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 10 March 2005: (1) Did the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control enter into force generally on 27 February 2005. (2) With which countries has Australia communicated about the Convention since Australia became a party to it on 27 October 2004. (3) What were the dates, subjects and outcomes of the communications with those countries. (1) Yes. (2) Departmental representatives attended the second Open-ended Intergovernmental Working Group (IGWG) on the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) in Geneva from 31 January to 4 February 2005. Delegation members interacted formally and informally with a large number of other delegations. A full list of participants at the meeting is available from the House of Representatives Table Office. During the period December 2004 to February 2005, the two months leading up to the second session of the Open-ended Intergovernmental Working Group on the FCTC, there were a number of informal communications at Departmental level with New Zealand, Canada and Japan. Departmental representatives attended a session of the first meeting of the Pacific Senior Health Officials Network on 26 November 2004. The Network meeting was attended by representatives from Fiji, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Samoa, Vanuatu, Tonga and Nauru. (3) The IGWG meeting held in Geneva from 31 January 2005 to 4 February 2005 discussed a number of matters that will be referred to the first FCTC Conference of the Parties (COP), particularly the arrangement for the permanent secretariat and the Rules of Procedure for the COP. Various models for the secretariat were discussed and several principles agreed, including housing of the secretariat within World Health Organization (WHO) and the need for maximum synergy between the secretariat and other WHO programs, especially the Tobacco Free Initiative, to avoid duplication and ensure value for money. There was agreement that the secretariat arrangements need to be reviewed after two years. Many of the draft Rules of Procedure were agreed but some key issues (status of non-Party country observers, involvement by non-governmental organisations, and procedures for consensus decision making) will need to be further considered by the COP. The IGWG also agreed that the COP should follow the financial rules of the World Health Assembly. The meeting also reviewed the terms of reference for a study of actual and potential sources of financial assistance for the implementation of the FCTC. This will be undertaken by the WHO To-
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:bacco Free Initiative as interim secretariat to the COP. The outcomes of this meeting are expected to be available on the World Health Organization website www.who.int/tobacco/framework. While the IGWG meeting inevitably focussed on administrative detail, these discussions played an important role in establishing the necessary infrastructure for the COP to begin consideration of substantive tobacco control issues such as product regulation and cross-border advertising. Informal communications with New Zealand, Canada and Japan during December 2004 and January 2005 included topics such as countries views on the approach to be taken at the upcoming Working Group meeting. These communications provided Australia with an understanding of these countries broad policy position on matters such as the secretariat for the Convention’s Conference of the Parties. The session of Pacific Senior Health Officials Network meeting attended by Departmental representatives on 26 November 2004 discussed various matters on tobacco including the economic impact of tobacco in the region and the FCTC. There was general understanding that through the Network there would be benefit from future exchanges about tobacco policy issues. The Pacific Senior Health Officials Network aims to support the Australian Government’s agenda of public sector capacity building by pooling expertise and skills to meet shared health challenges, create linkages between the Department of Health and Ageing and Health Ministries in the Pacific, facilitate communication and provide opportunities to work together and share best practice. (Question No. 786) Mr Melham asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 10 March 2005: (1) With which countries has the Government communicated about the 1989 Unesco Convention on Technical and Vocational Education. (2) What were the dates, circumstances and results of the communications. Australia has not signed the 1989 UNESCO Convention on Technical and Vocational Education, and there is no record of formal communications with other countries on this subject. The Convention was, however, an item of discussion between Australian and other participants at the Adelaide over 26-28 March 2001. More than 200 participants representing 37 countries from Asia, the Pacific, Europe and North America attended the Conference, which was co-sponsored by UNESCO, AusAID, the then Commonwealth Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs, the then South Australian Department of Education, Training and Employment and the Australian National Training Authority. The outcomes of the Conference discussions can be found at: www2.tafe.sa.edu.au/institutes/adelaide/unevoc/2001conf/summary_report.html Apprenticeships (Question No. 789) Ms Grierson asked the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education, in writing, on 10 March 2005: (1) How many first year apprentices, by trade, were employed in the electoral division of Newcastle in (a) 2001, (b) 2002, (c) 2003, and (d) 2004. (2) How many first year apprentices, by trade, were employed in 1996 in the electoral division of Newcastle.
